{"uri": "8262646047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "00:54:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T00:54:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T00:43:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/boxer-imane-khelif-advances-to-gold-medal-bout-with-another-victory-amid-gender-misconceptions/article_0c6aa021-4698-54fe-a998-0ada9c57fd03.html", "title": "Boxer Imane Khelif advances to gold-medal bout with another victory amid gender misconceptions", "body": "Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand, left, looks on after Match Referee Shawn Reese raises the arm of Imane Khelif of Algeria to announce the winner of their women's 66kg semifinal boxing match, at the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, Aug. 6, 2024, in Paris, France.\n\nPARIS (AP) -- Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria advanced to the gold-medal bout in the women's welterweight division at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night, moving one win away from what she calls the best response to the worldwide scrutiny she has faced over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nWith one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal and its first in women's boxing.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared for her and chanted her name repeatedly during her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday against Yang Liu of China.\n\n\"I am very happy,\" Khelif said through an interpreter. \"I've worked eight years for these Olympics, and I'm very proud of this moment. I would like to thank the support from people back home.\"\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier. She then controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing 8-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches.\n\n\"My opponent was really good,\" Khelif said. \"But I trained for two weeks, and I learned how she fought from videos.\"\n\nKhelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris. She has made the most important tournament run of her international career amid criticism and stigmatization stemming from the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association's decision to disqualify her and fellow Paris medalist Lin Yu-ting of Chinese Taipei from the world championships last year for allegedly failing an eligibility test.\n\n\"I had heard about the news regarding her, but I wasn't following it closely,\" Suwannapheng said. \"She is a woman, but she is very strong.\"\n\nThe ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the center of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender. Carini later apologized for her decision.\n\nIn an interview Sunday with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nKhelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal -- and now she's one win away.\n\nAfter sharing a hug with Suwannapheng, Khelif celebrated in the ring by running joyously in place while pumping her fists as the crowd roared for her again. The celebration was more joyous than her cathartic finish to her quarterfinal victory over Hungary's Anna Luca Hamori, when she slammed her palm on the canvas as she teared up.\n\nKhelif received her post-fight medical check and was headed out of the Roland Garros arena when she was mobbed by fans near the exit. They hugged Khelif, demanded selfies and waved Algerian flags while she made her way backstage.\n\nKhelif received cheers that echoed through the famed tennis arena from the moment she entered to face Suwannapheng. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose negative spotlight has been taken quite personally in her country.\n\nBoth fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.\n\nThe fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing 8-count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary -- as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\n\"I tried to use my speed, but my opponent was just too strong,\" Suwannapheng said.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif is on the best run of her amateur career at the Olympics. She has performed solidly at the international level and even won some regional tournaments, but Khelif has never been a dominant fighter on the world stage until her two strong performances -- and 46 seconds of easy work against a third -- to reach the final in Paris.\n\nThe IOC and its president, Thomas Bach, have repeatedly defended the Olympic eligibility of Khelif and Lin while condemning the IBA as incompetent and biased.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the IBA in the middle of last year's world championships over what it claimed were failed eligibility tests for the women's competition. The IBA has been banished from the Olympics since before the Tokyo Games, and the body struggled to articulate the reasoning for its decisions on Khelif and Lin at a news conference Monday.\n\nLin also has clinched a medal and advanced to the Olympic semifinals. She fights Esra Yildiz Kahraman of Turkey on Wednesday night.\n\nAlgeria's Olympic team has reacted forcefully to the criticism and negative attention around Khelif, and the fan turnout in Roland Garros reflected the seriousness with which the accusations have been received in her home country and in its French diaspora.\n\nChinese Taipei has reacted with equal condemnation of the IBA's claims and the worldwide swirl of scrutiny. Sports officials on Tuesday said they are considering legal action against the IBA after sending a letter protesting \"the International Boxing Association's continued publication of false information, obscuring the facts, and attempting to interfere with the normal conduct of the event regardless of the rights and interests of athletes.\"\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "greg_beacham@eagletribune.com", "name": {"uri": "8262569118", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "23:07:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T23:07:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T23:06:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/boxing/article-13716447/Gender-scandal-boxer-Imane-Khelif-bursts-WILD-celebrations-inside-ring-securing-place-Olympic-final-claiming-doesnt-care-controversy.html", "title": "Imane Khelif celebrates wildly after reaching Olympic final", "body": "By Mark Staniforth, Pa Olympics Correspondent and Mail Sport Staff\n\nImane Khelif exploded with joy after reaching the Olympic final in the women's 66kg boxing event thanks to another dominant display on Tuesday night.\n\nThe 25-year-old overcame Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng by a unanimous decision to set up a gold medal fight against Yang Liu of China.\n\nOnce her victory was confirmed over the loudspeaker, Khelif began celebrating by waving the index finger on her left hand.\n\nShe then briefly paused her celebrations to allow her opponent - now a confirmed bronze medalist - a moment to lap up applause from the crowd.\n\nOnce Suwannapheng had left the ring, Khelif returned to centre stage and began running on the spot with high knees, while spinning around and appeared to shout something.\n\nImane Khelif (right) progressed to the final of the women's 66kg boxing event on Tuesday\n\nKhelif secured a victory via unanimous decision over Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand\n\nShortly after her win was confirmed, Algerian Khelif celebrated wildly by dancing in the ring\n\nLater in the evening, Khelif said that she did not care about the controversy swirling over her inclusion in the women's 66kg boxing category.\n\nHaving avoided the huge media scrum after her previous bouts, Khelif broke her silence to maintain: 'I don't care what anyone is saying about me with the controversy.\n\n'All that is important to me is that I stay on the level and give my people the performance they deserve. I know I'm a talented person and this is a gift to all Algerians.'\n\nHundreds of flag-waving Algerian supporters had turned the normally genteel surroundings of Phillippe-Chatrier Court at Roland Garros into a cauldron of noise in support of Khelif, who is at the centre of a gender eligibility row.\n\nChants of 'Imane' tumbled down from the stands as Khelif, who was one of two boxers caught up in the ongoing row, dominated Suwannapheng to confirm she will get the chance to emulate compatriot Hocine Soltani, who won lightweight gold in 1996.\n\nThe participation of Khelif and Chinese Taipei featherweight Lin Yu-ting has caused an international storm since Khelif beat Angela Carini of Italy in just 46 seconds in her opening bout last Thursday.\n\nThe crowd around the Phillippe-Chatrier Court was full of Algerian supporters and flags\n\nKhelif said later on Tuesday: 'I don't care what anyone is saying about me with the controversy'\n\nBoth Khelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association (IBA) during last year's World Championships for failing to meet gender eligibility criteria.\n\nHowever, the IBA, which was was expelled by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) over financial and corruption concerns, has failed to provide any proof of its findings.\n\nOn Monday, an IBA press conference descended into farce as controversial president Umar Kremlev made baseless claims about Lin and Khelif and launched an astonishing tirade against IOC president Thomas Bach.\n\nKhelif and Lin were allowed to return to competition by the IOC, which is effectively administering the Paris 2024 boxing tournament in the IBA's absence.\n\nThe case has aroused global interest, with figures such as former United States president Donald Trump and Harry Potter author JK Rowling weighing in on the issue.\n\nKhelif won every round on the judges' cards on Tuesday night, appearing close to securing a stoppage at times.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8262666616", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "01:12:22", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T01:12:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T01:11:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/sports/olympics/summer/boxing/boxing-paris-olympic-semifinal-aug-6-1.7286683", "title": "Algeria's Imane Khelif to fight for gold after winning women's welterweight semifinal | CBC Sports", "body": "Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria advanced to the gold-medal bout in the women's welterweight division at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night, moving one win away from what she calls the best response to the worldwide scrutiny she has faced over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nWith one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal and its first in women's boxing.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared for her and chanted her name repeatedly during her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday against Yang Liu of China.\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier. She then controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing 8-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches.\n\n\"My opponent was really good,\" Khelif said. \"But I trained for two weeks, and I learned how she fought from videos.\"\n\nKhelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris. She has made the most important tournament run of her international career amid criticism and stigmatisation stemming from the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association's decision to disqualify her and fellow Paris medallist Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan from the world championships last year for allegedly failing an eligibility test.\n\n\"I had heard about the news regarding her, but I wasn't following it closely,\" Suwannapheng said. \"She is a woman, but she is very strong.\"\n\nWATCH | Former IOC medical adviser weighs in on women's Olympic boxing discussion:\n\nThe ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the centre of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. president Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender. Carini later apologized for her decision.\n\nIn an interview Sunday with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nKhelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal -- and now she's one win away.\n\nKhelif received her post-fight medical check and was headed out of the Roland Garros arena when she was mobbed by fans near the exit. They hugged Khelif, demanded selfies and waved Algerian flags while she made her way backstage.\n\nKhelif received cheers that echoed through the famed tennis arena from the moment she entered to face Suwannapheng. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose negative spotlight has been taken quite personally in her country.\n\nBoth fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.\n\nThe fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing 8-count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary -- as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\n\"I tried to use my speed, but my opponent was just too strong,\" Suwannapheng said.\n\nWATCH | Khelif defeats Carlini at Paris Olympics:\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif is on the best run of her amateur career at the Olympics. She has performed solidly at the international level and even won some regional tournaments, but Khelif has never been a dominant fighter on the world stage until her two strong performances -- and 46 seconds of easy work against a third -- to reach the final in Paris.\n\nThe IOC and its president, Thomas Bach, have repeatedly defended the Olympic eligibility of Khelif and Lin while condemning the IBA as incompetent and biased.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the IBA in the middle of last year's world championships over what it claimed were failed eligibility tests for the women's competition. The IBA has been banished from the Olympics since before the Tokyo Games, and the body struggled to articulate the reasoning for its decisions on Khelif and Lin at a news conference Monday.\n\nAlgeria's Olympic team has reacted forcefully to the criticism and negative attention around Khelif, and the fan turnout in Roland Garros reflected the seriousness with which the accusations have been received in her home country and in its French diaspora.\n\nChinese Taipei has reacted with equal condemnation of the IBA's claims and the worldwide swirl of scrutiny. Sports officials on Tuesday said they are considering legal action against the IBA after sending a letter protesting \"the International Boxing Association's continued publication of false information, obscuring the facts, and attempting to interfere with the normal conduct of the event regardless of the rights and interests of athletes.\"", "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "dataType": "https://i.cbc.ca/1.7286983.1722992323!/fileImage/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/16x9_620/2165108017.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9796155", "eventUri": "eng-9796155", {"uri": "2024-08-446272336", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "00:08:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T00:08:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:23:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.clickondetroit.com/sports/2024/08/06/boxer-imane-khelif-fights-to-get-closer-to-olympic-gold-amid-outcry-over-gender-misconceptions/", "title": "Boxer Imane Khelif advances to gold-medal bout with another victory amid gender misconceptions", "body": "PARIS - Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria advanced to the gold-medal bout in the women's welterweight division at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night, moving one win away from what she calls the best response to the worldwide scrutiny she has faced over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nWith one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal and its first in women's boxing.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared for her and chanted her name repeatedly during her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday against Yang Liu of China.\n\n\"I am very happy,\" Khelif said through an interpreter. \"I've worked eight years for these Olympics, and I'm very proud of this moment. I would like to thank the support from people back home.\"\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier. She then controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing 8-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches.\n\n\"My opponent was really good,\" Khelif said. \"But I trained for two weeks, and I learned how she fought from videos.\"\n\nKhelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris. She has made the most important tournament run of her international career amid criticism and stigmatization stemming from the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association's decision to disqualify her and fellow Paris medalist Lin Yu-ting of Chinese Taipei from the world championships last year for allegedly failing an eligibility test.\n\n\"I had heard about the news regarding her, but I wasn't following it closely,\" Suwannapheng said. \"She is a woman, but she is very strong.\"\n\nThe ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the center of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender. Carini later apologized for her decision.\n\nIn an interview Sunday with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nKhelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal -- and now she's one win away.\n\nAfter sharing a hug with Suwannapheng, Khelif celebrated in the ring by running joyously in place while pumping her fists as the crowd roared for her again. The celebration was more joyous than her cathartic finish to her quarterfinal victory over Hungary's Anna Luca Hamori, when she slammed her palm on the canvas as she teared up.\n\nKhelif received her post-fight medical check and was headed out of the Roland Garros arena when she was mobbed by fans near the exit. They hugged Khelif, demanded selfies and waved Algerian flags while she made her way backstage.\n\nKhelif received cheers that echoed through the famed tennis arena from the moment she entered to face Suwannapheng. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose negative spotlight has been taken quite personally in her country.\n\nBoth fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.\n\nThe fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing 8-count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary -- as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\n\"I tried to use my speed, but my opponent was just too strong,\" Suwannapheng said.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif is on the best run of her amateur career at the Olympics. She has performed solidly at the international level and even won some regional tournaments, but Khelif has never been a dominant fighter on the world stage until her two strong performances -- and 46 seconds of easy work against a third -- to reach the final in Paris.\n\nThe IOC and its president, Thomas Bach, have repeatedly defended the Olympic eligibility of Khelif and Lin while condemning the IBA as incompetent and biased.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the IBA in the middle of last year's world championships over what it claimed were failed eligibility tests for the women's competition. The IBA has been banished from the Olympics since before the Tokyo Games, and the body struggled to articulate the reasoning for its decisions on Khelif and Lin at a news conference Monday.\n\nLin also has clinched a medal and advanced to the Olympic semifinals. She fights Esra Yildiz Kahraman of Turkey on Wednesday night.\n\nAlgeria's Olympic team has reacted forcefully to the criticism and negative attention around Khelif, and the fan turnout in Roland Garros reflected the seriousness with which the accusations have been received in her home country and in its French diaspora.\n\nChinese Taipei has reacted with equal condemnation of the IBA's claims and the worldwide swirl of scrutiny. Sports officials on Tuesday said they are considering legal action against the IBA after sending a letter protesting \"the International Boxing Association's continued publication of false information, obscuring the facts, and attempting to interfere with the normal conduct of the event regardless of the rights and interests of athletes.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Olympics: {"uri": "2024-08-446218653", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:17:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:17:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:50:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.ksn.com/news/boxer-imane-khelif-advances-to-gold-medal-bout-with-another-victory-amid-gender-misconceptions/", "title": "Boxer Imane Khelif advances to gold-medal bout with another victory amid gender misconceptions", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria advanced to the gold-medal bout in the women's welterweight division at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night, moving one win away from what she calls the best response to the worldwide scrutiny she has faced over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nWith one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal and its first in women's boxing.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared for her and chanted her name repeatedly during her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday against Yang Liu of China.\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nShe then controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing 8-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches. Khelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris.\n\nAfter hugging Suwannapheng, Khelif celebrated in the ring, running joyously in place while pumping her fists as the crowd roared for her again. Khelif received her post-fight medical check and was headed out of the arena when she was mobbed by fans near the exit. They hugged Khelif, demanded selfies and waved Algerian flags while she made her way backstage.\n\nThe ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the center of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender.\n\nIn an interview with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nKhelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal -- and now she's one win away.\n\nKhelif entered the ring against Suwannapheng to cheers echoing through the famed tennis arena. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose stigmatization by the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association has been taken very personally in her country.\n\nBoth fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.\n\nThe fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing 8-count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary -- as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif is on the best run of her amateur career at the Olympics. She has performed solidly at the international level and even won some regional tournaments, but Khelif has never been a dominant fighter on the world stage until her two strong performances -- and 46 seconds of easy work against a third -- to reach the final in Paris.\n\nThe IOC and its president, Thomas Bach, have repeatedly defended the Olympic eligibility of Khelif and fellow boxer Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan while condemning the IBA as incompetent and biased.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the IBA in the middle of last year's world championships over what it claimed were failed eligibility tests for the women's competition. The IBA has been banished from the Olympics since before the Tokyo Games, and the body struggled to articulate the reasoning for its decisions on Khelif and Lin at a news conference Monday.\n\nLin also has clinched a medal and advanced to the Olympic semifinals. She fights Esra Yildiz Kahraman of Turkey in the first bout Wednesday night at Roland Garros.\n\nAlgeria's Olympic team has reacted forcefully to the criticism and negative attention around Khelif, and the fan turnout in Roland Garros reflected the seriousness with which the accusations have been received in her home country and in its French diaspora.\n\nChinese Taipei has reacted with equal condemnation of the IBA's claims and the worldwide swirl of scrutiny. Sports officials on Tuesday said they are considering legal action against the IBA after sending a letter protesting \"the International Boxing Association's continued publication of false information, obscuring the facts, and attempting to interfere with the normal conduct of the event regardless of the rights and interests of athletes.\"", "source": {"uri": "ksn.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-08-446216044", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:13:31", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:13:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T13:23:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://mynorthwest.com/3974356/boxer-imane-khelif-advances-to-gold-medal-bout-with-another-victory-amid-gender-misconceptions/", "title": "Boxer Imane Khelif advances to gold-medal bout with another victory amid gender misconceptions", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria advanced to the gold-medal bout in the women's welterweight division at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night, moving one win away from what she calls the best response to the worldwide scrutiny she has faced over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nWith one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal and its first in women's boxing.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared for her and chanted her name repeatedly during her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday against Yang Liu of China.\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier. She then controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing 8-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches.\n\nKhelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris. She has made the most important tournament run of her international career amid criticism and stigmatization stemming from the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association's decision to disqualify her from the world championships last year for allegedly failing an eligibility test.\n\n\"I had heard about the news regarding her, but I wasn't following it closely,\" Suwannapheng said. \"She is a woman, but she is very strong.\"\n\nThe ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the center of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender.\n\nIn an interview with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nKhelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal -- and now she's one win away.\n\nAfter sharing a hug with Suwannapheng, Khelif celebrated in the ring by running joyously in place while pumping her fists as the crowd roared for her again. The celebration was more joyous than her cathartic finish to her quarterfinal victory over Hungary's Anna Luca Hamori, when she slammed her palm on the canvas as she teared up.\n\nKhelif received her post-fight medical check and was headed out of the Roland Garros arena when she was mobbed by fans near the exit. They hugged Khelif, demanded selfies and waved Algerian flags while she made her way backstage.\n\nKhelif received cheers that echoed through the famed tennis arena from the moment she entered to face Suwannapheng. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose negative spotlight has been taken quite personally in her country.\n\nBoth fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.\n\nThe fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing 8-count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary -- as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\n\"I tried to use my speed, but my opponent was just too strong,\" Suwannapheng said.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif is on the best run of her amateur career at the Olympics. She has performed solidly at the international level and even won some regional tournaments, but Khelif has never been a dominant fighter on the world stage until her two strong performances -- and 46 seconds of easy work against a third -- to reach the final in Paris.\n\nThe IOC and its president, Thomas Bach, have repeatedly defended the Olympic eligibility of Khelif and fellow boxer Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan while condemning the IBA as incompetent and biased.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the IBA in the middle of last year's world championships over what it claimed were failed eligibility tests for the women's competition. The IBA has been banished from the Olympics since before the Tokyo Games, and the body struggled to articulate the reasoning for its decisions on Khelif and Lin at a news conference Monday.\n\nLin also has clinched a medal and advanced to the Olympic semifinals. She fights Esra Yildiz Kahraman of Turkey on Wednesday night.\n\nAlgeria's Olympic team has reacted forcefully to the criticism and negative attention around Khelif, and the fan turnout in Roland Garros reflected the seriousness with which the accusations have been received in her home country and in its French diaspora.\n\nChinese Taipei has reacted with equal condemnation of the IBA's claims and the worldwide swirl of scrutiny. Sports officials on Tuesday said they are considering legal action against the IBA after sending a letter protesting \"the International Boxing Association's continued publication of false information, obscuring the facts, and attempting to interfere with the normal conduct of the event regardless of the rights and interests of athletes.\"\n\n___\n\nAP Olympics: {"uri": "8262572921", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "23:11:19", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T23:11:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T23:10:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://gvwire.com/2024/08/06/boxer-imane-khelif-advances-to-gold-medal-bout-with-another-victory-amid-gender-misconceptions/", "title": "Boxer Imane Khelif Advances to Gold-Medal Bout With Another Victory Amid Gender Misconceptions", "body": "PARIS -- Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria advanced to the gold-medal bout in the women's welterweight division at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night, moving one win away from what she calls the best response to the worldwide scrutiny she has faced over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nWith one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal and its first in women's boxing.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared for her and chanted her name repeatedly during her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday against Yang Liu of China.\n\n\"I am very happy,\" Khelif said through an interpreter. \"I've worked eight years for these Olympics, and I'm very proud of this moment. I would like to thank the support from people back home.\"\n\nRelated Story: Boxer Imane Khelif Fights to Get Closer to Olympic Gold Amid Outcry Over Gender ...\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier. She then controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing 8-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches.\n\n\"My opponent was really good,\" Khelif said. \"But I trained for two weeks, and I learned how she fought from videos.\"\n\nKhelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris. She has made the most important tournament run of her international career amid criticism and stigmatization stemming from the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association's decision to disqualify her and fellow Paris medalist Lin Yu-ting of Chinese Taipei from the world championships last year for allegedly failing an eligibility test.\n\n\"I had heard about the news regarding her, but I wasn't following it closely,\" Suwannapheng said. \"She is a woman, but she is very strong.\"\n\nRelated Story: Who Is Imane Khelif? Algerian Boxer Facing Gender Outcry Had Modest Success ...\n\nThe ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the center of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender. Carini later apologized for her decision.\n\nIn an interview Sunday with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nKhelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal -- and now she's one win away.\n\nRelated Story: IOC Rejects IBA's Gender Tests, Allows Disputed Female Boxers to Continue\n\nAfter sharing a hug with Suwannapheng, Khelif celebrated in the ring by running joyously in place while pumping her fists as the crowd roared for her again. The celebration was more joyous than her cathartic finish to her quarterfinal victory over Hungary's Anna Luca Hamori, when she slammed her palm on the canvas as she teared up.\n\nKhelif received her post-fight medical check and was headed out of the Roland Garros arena when she was mobbed by fans near the exit. They hugged Khelif, demanded selfies and waved Algerian flags while she made her way backstage.\n\nKhelif received cheers that echoed through the famed tennis arena from the moment she entered to face Suwannapheng. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose negative spotlight has been taken quite personally in her country.\n\nBoth fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.\n\nThe fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing 8-count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary -- as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\n\"I tried to use my speed, but my opponent was just too strong,\" Suwannapheng said.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif is on the best run of her amateur career at the Olympics. She has performed solidly at the international level and even won some regional tournaments, but Khelif has never been a dominant fighter on the world stage until her two strong performances -- and 46 seconds of easy work against a third -- to reach the final in Paris.\n\nThe IOC and its president, Thomas Bach, have repeatedly defended the Olympic eligibility of Khelif and Lin while condemning the IBA as incompetent and biased.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the IBA in the middle of last year's world championships over what it claimed were failed eligibility tests for the women's competition. The IBA has been banished from the Olympics since before the Tokyo Games, and the body struggled to articulate the reasoning for its decisions on Khelif and Lin at a news conference Monday.\n\nLin also has clinched a medal and advanced to the Olympic semifinals. She fights Esra Yildiz Kahraman of Turkey on Wednesday night.\n\nAlgeria's Olympic team has reacted forcefully to the criticism and negative attention around Khelif, and the fan turnout in Roland Garros reflected the seriousness with which the accusations have been received in her home country and in its French diaspora.\n\nChinese Taipei has reacted with equal condemnation of the IBA's claims and the worldwide swirl of scrutiny. Sports officials on Tuesday said they are considering legal action against the IBA after sending a letter protesting \"the International Boxing Association's continued publication of false information, obscuring the facts, and attempting to interfere with the normal conduct of the event regardless of the rights and interests of athletes.\"", "source": {"uri": "gvwire.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8262540157", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:31:02", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:31:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T22:30:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/boxer-imane-khelif-advances-to-gold-medal-bout", "title": "Boxer Imane Khelif advances to gold-medal bout", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria advanced to the gold-medal bout in the women's welterweight division at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night, moving one win away from what she calls the best response to the worldwide scrutiny she has faced over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nWith one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal and its first in women's boxing.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared for her and chanted her name repeatedly during her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday against Yang Liu of China.\n\nREAD MORE: Olympic boxer Imane Khelif says misconceptions about her gender 'harms human dignity'\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier. She then controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing 8-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches.\n\nKhelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris. She has made the most important tournament run of her international career amid criticism and stigmatization stemming from the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association's decision to disqualify her from the world championships last year for allegedly failing an eligibility test.\n\n\"I had heard about the news regarding her, but I wasn't following it closely,\" Suwannapheng said. \"She is a woman, but she is very strong.\"\n\nThe ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the center of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender.\n\nREAD MORE: Are the 2024 Paris Olympics gender equal? That depends how you measure it\n\nIn an interview with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nKhelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal -- and now she's one win away.\n\nAfter sharing a hug with Suwannapheng, Khelif celebrated in the ring by running joyously in place while pumping her fists as the crowd roared for her again. The celebration was more joyous than her cathartic finish to her quarterfinal victory over Hungary's Anna Luca Hamori, when she slammed her palm on the canvas as she teared up.\n\nKhelif received her post-fight medical check and was headed out of the Roland Garros arena when she was mobbed by fans near the exit. They hugged Khelif, demanded selfies and waved Algerian flags while she made her way backstage.\n\nKhelif received cheers that echoed through the famed tennis arena from the moment she entered to face Suwannapheng. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose negative spotlight has been taken quite personally in her country.\n\nBoth fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.\n\nThe fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing 8-count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary -- as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\n\"I tried to use my speed, but my opponent was just too strong,\" Suwannapheng said.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif is on the best run of her amateur career at the Olympics. She has performed solidly at the international level and even won some regional tournaments, but Khelif has never been a dominant fighter on the world stage until her two strong performances -- and 46 seconds of easy work against a third -- to reach the final in Paris.\n\nThe IOC and its president, Thomas Bach, have repeatedly defended the Olympic eligibility of Khelif and fellow boxer Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan while condemning the IBA as incompetent and biased.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the IBA in the middle of last year's world championships over what it claimed were failed eligibility tests for the women's competition. The IBA has been banished from the Olympics since before the Tokyo Games, and the body struggled to articulate the reasoning for its decisions on Khelif and Lin at a news conference Monday.\n\nLin also has clinched a medal and advanced to the Olympic semifinals. She fights Esra Yildiz Kahraman of Turkey on Wednesday night.\n\nAlgeria's Olympic team has reacted forcefully to the criticism and negative attention around Khelif, and the fan turnout in Roland Garros reflected the seriousness with which the accusations have been received in her home country and in its French diaspora.\n\nChinese Taipei has reacted with equal condemnation of the IBA's claims and the worldwide swirl of scrutiny. Sports officials on Tuesday said they are considering legal action against the IBA after sending a letter protesting \"the International Boxing Association's continued publication of false {"uri": "8262627871", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "00:21:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T00:21:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T00:19:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.espn.in/olympics/story/_/id/40752620/boxer-imane-khelif-dominant-again-gold-medal-bout", "title": "Boxer Khelif dominant again, into gold medal bout", "body": "PARIS -- Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria advanced to the gold medal bout in the women's welterweight division at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night, moving one win away from what she calls the best response to the worldwide scrutiny she has faced over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nWith one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal and its first in women's boxing.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5-0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared and chanted her name throughout her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday against Yang Liu of China.\n\n\"I am very happy,\" Khelif said through an interpreter. \"I've worked eight years for these Olympics, and I'm very proud of this moment. I would like to thank the support from people back home.\"\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier. She controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing eight count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches.\n\n\"My opponent was really good,\" Khelif said. \"But I trained for two weeks, and I learned how she fought from videos.\"\n\nKhelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris. She has made the most important tournament run of her international career amid criticism and stigmatization stemming from the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association's decision to disqualify her and fellow Paris medalist Lin Yu-ting of Chinese Taipei from the world championships last year for allegedly failing an eligibility test.\n\n\"I had heard about the news regarding her, but I wasn't following it closely,\" Suwannapheng said. \"She is a woman, but she is very strong.\"\n\nThe ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the center of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender.\n\nIn an interview with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nKhelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal -- and now she's one win away from claiming it.\n\nAfter sharing a hug with Suwannapheng, Khelif celebrated in the ring by running joyously in place while pumping her fists as the crowd roared for her again. The celebration was more joyous than her cathartic finish to her quarterfinal victory over Hungary's Anna Luca Hamori, when she slammed her palm on the canvas as she teared up.\n\nKhelif received her post-fight medical check and was headed out of the Roland Garros arena when she was mobbed by fans near the exit. They hugged Khelif, demanded selfies and waved Algerian flags while she made her way backstage.\n\nKhelif received cheers that echoed through the famed tennis arena from the moment she entered to face Suwannapheng. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose negative spotlight has been taken quite personally in her country.\n\nBoth fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.\n\nThe fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing eight count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary -- as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\n\"I tried to use my speed, but my opponent was just too strong,\" Suwannapheng said.\n\nKhelif, 25, is on the best run of her amateur career at the Olympics. She has performed solidly at the international level and even won some regional tournaments, but Khelif has never been a dominant fighter on the world stage until her two strong performances -- and 46 seconds of easy work against a third -- to reach the final in Paris.\n\nThe IOC and its president, Thomas Bach, have repeatedly defended the Olympic eligibility of Khelif and Lin while condemning the IBA as incompetent and biased.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the IBA in the middle of last year's world championships over what it claimed were failed eligibility tests for the women's competition. The IBA has been banished from the Olympics since before the Tokyo Games.\n\nLin also has clinched a medal and advanced to the Olympic semifinals. She fights Esra Yildiz Kahraman of Turkey in the first bout Wednesday night at Roland Garros.\n\nAlgeria's Olympic team has reacted forcefully to the criticism and negative attention around Khelif, and the fan turnout in Roland Garros reflected the seriousness with which the accusations have been received in her home country and in its French diaspora.\n\nChinese Taipei has reacted with equal condemnation of the IBA's claims and the worldwide swirl of scrutiny. Sports officials on Tuesday said they are considering legal action against the IBA after sending a letter protesting \"the International Boxing Association's continued publication of false information, obscuring the facts, and attempting to interfere with the normal conduct of the event regardless of the rights and interests of athletes.\"", "source": {"uri": "espn.in", "dataType": {"uri": "8262591047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "23:34:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T23:34:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T23:33:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/sport/524399/algerian-khelif-wins-olympics-women-s-boxing-semi-final-amid-gender-dispute", "title": "Algerian Khelif wins Olympics women's boxing semi-final amid gender dispute", "body": "Imane Khelif, the boxer at the centre of a gender dispute, beat Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng by unanimous decision in a welterweight semi-final fight at the Paris Olympics to progress to the women's final at Roland Garros.\n\nKhelif, a silver medallist at the 2022 worlds, and Taiwanese boxer Lin Yu-ting have been in the spotlight at the Olympics as part of a storm that has dominated headlines and been the subject of much discussion on social media platforms.\n\n\"I don't want anything to be said about the controversy,\" Khelif said after her win.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association from the 2023 World Championships in New Delhi, with the body saying in a shambolic press conference on Tuesday that a sex chromosome test had ruled both of them ineligible.\n\nAt those World Championships, Khelif beat Suwannapheng by unanimous decision in the semi-finals before being disqualified. Suwannapheng competed in the final after Khelif's disqualification and won silver.\n\nKhelif and Lin are competing in the Olympics after the International Olympic Committee stripped the IBA of its status as the sport's governing body in 2023 and took control of organising the boxing in Paris.\n\nThe IOC has rejected the results of the IBA-ordered tests as arbitrary and illegitimate, saying there was no reason to conduct them.\n\nAt these Games, the IOC is using boxing eligibility rules that were applied at the 2016 and 2021 Olympics which do not include gender testing.\n\nAlgerian fans flocked into a repurposed Court Philippe Chatrier, devoid of its iconic red clay, looking to support Khelif and screamed \"Imane, Imane, Imane\" ahead of the bout, while also booing Suwannapheng on entry.\n\nIn a cautious first round, both boxers attempted to keep their distance and engaged sparingly, but Khelif used her jab to better effect than her Thai opponent.\n\nSuwannapheng connected with a big right hand in the second, but the rangy Algerian's excellent technique allowed her to keep landing shots and sweep the judge's scorecards.\n\nKhelif threw caution to the wind and went after Suwannapheng in the final round, peppering her with jarring shots to claim the win by unanimous decision.\n\nBoth boxers touched gloves in a sign of respect after the fight, and when Khelif was announced as winner a deafening roar erupted from the fans in attendance.\n\n\"I just had the performance I was looking to deliver today to make the fans happy,\" Khelif said.\n\nKhelif waited until her opponent left the ring before celebrating, jogging on the spot with an enormous grin on her face before leaving and shadow-boxing her way to the doctor's station for a quick medical check.\n\n\"I have not followed the controversy closely but all I know is that she is a woman and she is a strong fighter,\" Suwannapheng said.\n\nKhelif will face Yang Liu of China in the final on Friday.\n\nLin also reached the semi-finals in the featherweight category, where she will take on Turkey's Esra Yildiz on Wednesday.\n\nThe storm surrounding Khelif and Lin erupted when the Algerian's opponent Angela Carini pulled out of their round-of-16 bout last week after just 46 seconds, saying she felt intense pain and feared for her safety after being hit with a barrage of punches.\n\nIn the aftermath of Carini's withdrawal, the gender furore swept social media, with people such as Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling and Tesla founder Elon Musk voicing their opposition to the two boxers competing at the Games.\n\nFollowing the bout, Italian Carini apologised to Khelif and said she did not harbour any ill {"uri": "8262511797", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:01:34", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:01:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T22:00:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.espn.ph/olympics/story/_/id/40752620/boxer-imane-khelif-dominant-again-gold-medal-bout", "title": "Boxer Khelif dominant again, into gold medal bout", "body": "PARIS -- Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria advanced to the gold medal bout in the women's welterweight division at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night, moving one win away from what she calls the best response to the worldwide scrutiny she has faced over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nWith one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal and its first in women's boxing.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5-0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared and chanted her name throughout her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday against Yang Liu of China.\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nShe controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing 8-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches. Khelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris.\n\nAfter hugging Suwannapheng, Khelif celebrated in the ring, running joyously in place while pumping her fists as the crowd roared for her again. Khelif received her post-fight medical check and was headed out of the arena when she was mobbed by fans near the exit. They hugged Khelif, demanded selfies and waved Algerian flags while she made her way backstage.\n\nThe ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the center of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender.\n\nIn an interview with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nKhelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal -- and now she's one win away from claiming it.\n\nKhelif entered the ring against Suwannapheng to cheers echoing through the famed tennis arena. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose stigmatization by the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association has been taken very personally in her country.\n\nBoth fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.\n\nThe fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing 8-count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary -- as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif is on the best run of her amateur career at the Olympics. She has performed solidly at the international level and even won some regional tournaments, but Khelif has never been a dominant fighter on the world stage until her two strong performances -- and 46 seconds of easy work against a third -- to reach the final in Paris.\n\nThe IOC and its president, Thomas Bach, have repeatedly defended the Olympic eligibility of Khelif and fellow boxer Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan while condemning the IBA as incompetent and biased.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the IBA in the middle of last year's world championships over what it claimed were failed eligibility tests for the women's competition. The IBA has been banished from the Olympics since before the Tokyo Games.\n\nLin also has clinched a medal and advanced to the Olympic semifinals. She fights Esra Yildiz Kahraman of Turkey in the first bout Wednesday night at Roland Garros.\n\nAlgeria's Olympic team has reacted forcefully to the criticism and negative attention around Khelif, and the fan turnout in Roland Garros reflected the seriousness with which the accusations have been received in her home country and in its French diaspora.\n\nChinese Taipei has reacted with equal condemnation of the IBA's claims and the worldwide swirl of scrutiny. Sports officials on Tuesday said they are considering legal action against the IBA after sending a letter protesting \"the International Boxing Association's continued publication of false information, obscuring the facts, and attempting to interfere with the normal conduct of the event regardless of the rights and interests of athletes.\"", "source": {"uri": "espn.ph", "dataType": {"uri": "8262509176", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:57:58", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:57:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:57:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.adn.com/sports/national-sports/2024/08/06/boxer-imane-khelif-advances-to-gold-medal-bout-amid-gender-misconceptions-and-scrutiny/", "title": "Boxer Imane Khelif advances to gold-medal bout amid gender misconceptions and scrutiny", "body": "PARIS -- Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria advanced to the gold-medal bout in the women's welterweight division at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night, moving one win away from what she calls the best response to the worldwide scrutiny she has faced over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nWith one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal and its first in women's boxing.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared for her and chanted her name repeatedly during her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday against Yang Liu of China.\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nShe then controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing 8-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches. Khelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris.\n\nAfter hugging Suwannapheng, Khelif celebrated in the ring, running joyously in place while pumping her fists as the crowd roared for her again. Khelif received her post-fight medical check and was headed out of the arena when she was mobbed by fans near the exit. They hugged Khelif, demanded selfies and waved Algerian flags while she made her way backstage.\n\nThe ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the center of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender.\n\nIn an interview with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nKhelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal -- and now she's one win away.\n\nKhelif entered the ring against Suwannapheng to cheers echoing through the famed tennis arena. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose stigmatization by the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association has been taken very personally in her country.\n\nBoth fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.\n\nThe fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing 8-count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary -- as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif is on the best run of her amateur career at the Olympics. She has performed solidly at the international level and even won some regional tournaments, but Khelif has never been a dominant fighter on the world stage until her two strong performances -- and 46 seconds of easy work against a third -- to reach the final in Paris.\n\nThe IOC and its president, Thomas Bach, have repeatedly defended the Olympic eligibility of Khelif and fellow boxer Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan while condemning the IBA as incompetent and biased.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the IBA in the middle of last year's world championships over what it claimed were failed eligibility tests for the women's competition. The IBA has been banished from the Olympics since before the Tokyo Games, and the body struggled to articulate the reasoning for its decisions on Khelif and Lin at a news conference Monday.\n\nLin also has clinched a medal and advanced to the Olympic semifinals. She fights Esra Yildiz Kahraman of Turkey in the first bout Wednesday night at Roland Garros.\n\nAlgeria's Olympic team has reacted forcefully to the criticism and negative attention around Khelif, and the fan turnout in Roland Garros reflected the seriousness with which the accusations have been received in her home country and in its French diaspora.\n\nChinese Taipei has reacted with equal condemnation of the IBA's claims and the worldwide swirl of scrutiny. Sports officials on Tuesday said they are considering legal action against the IBA after sending a letter protesting \"the International Boxing Association's continued publication of false information, obscuring the facts, and attempting to interfere with the normal conduct of the event regardless of the rights and interests of athletes.\"", "source": {"uri": "adn.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8262567013", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "23:04:54", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T23:04:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T23:03:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.gulf-times.com/article/688159/sports/khelif-wins-semi-final-amid-gender-row", "title": "Khelif wins semi-final amid gender row", "body": "Algeria's Imane Khelif celebrates after beating Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng in the women's 66kg semi-final during the Paris 2024 Olympic Games at the Roland-Garros Stadium in Paris on Tuesday. (AFP)\n\nThe Algerian boxer embroiled in a major gender controversy at the Paris Olympics won her semi-final match on Tuesday to guarantee at least a silver medal in front of a raucous Roland Garros crowd that chanted her name.\n\nImane Khelif defeated Thailand's 2023 world silver medallist Janjaem Suwannapheng in a unanimous points decision to march into Friday's final in the women's 66kg category.\n\nTaiwan's Lin Yu-ting, the other boxer in the eye of a storm over her eligibility, is herself sure to take home at least bronze at a different weight.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif and Lin both fought at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago but there was no controversy at the time and neither won a medal.\n\nBoth were disqualified from last year's world championships after failing gender eligibility tests, but were cleared to compete in Paris.\n\nKhelif was given the biggest roar of the night as she entered the arena at Roland Garros, usually home to Grand Slam tennis but hosting Olympic boxing and a sizeable number of Algerian fans with flags.\n\nCries of \"Imane, Imane\" rang out repeatedly before and during the bout. The Thai, who had a clear height disadvantage, took a standing count in the third round after feeling the full power of the superior Algerian.\n\nAt the end of the fight at the 15,000-seated Court Philippe Chatrier, which was close to capacity, the two fighters greeted each other warmly and shook hands.\n\nKhelif did a dance in the middle of the ring, to more roars of approval. Khelif faces China's Yang Liu or Taiwan's Chen Nien-chin for gold.\n\nThe gender controversy ignited when Khelif defeated Angela Carini in 46 seconds in her opening bout in the French capital, the Italian reduced to tears and abandoning the fight after suffering a badly hurt nose.\n\nThe 2023 world championships, from which Lin and Khelif were expelled, were run by the International Boxing Association (IBA) but the International Olympic Committee (IOC) is organising the sport at the Games because of financial, governance and ethical concerns at the IBA.\n\nThe IBA's Kremlin-linked president Umar Kremlev claimed at a chaotic press conference on Monday that both fighters had \"genetic testing that shows that these are men\".\n\nThe IOC has leapt to the defence of Khelif and Lin, with president Thomas Bach saying they were born and raised as women, and have passports saying that.", "source": {"uri": "gulf-times.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Gulf-Times"}, "authors": [], I know I'm a talented person and this is a gift to all Algerians.\"\n\nChants of \"Imane\" tumbled down from the stands as Khelif, who is one of two boxers caught up in the ongoing row, dominated Suwannapheng to confirm she will get the chance to emulate compatriot Hocine Soltani, who won lightweight gold in 1996.\n\nThe participation of Khelif and Chinese Taipei featherweight Lin Yu-ting has caused an international storm since Khelif beat Angela Carini of Italy in just 46 seconds in her opening bout last Thursday.\n\nBoth Khelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association (IBA) during last year's World Championships for failing to meet gender eligibility criteria.\n\nHowever, the IBA, which was was expelled by the International Olympic Commitee (IOC) over financial and corruption concerns, has failed to provide any proof of its findings.\n\nLin Yu-ting is the other fighter caught up in the controversy (Peter Byrne/PA)\n\nOn Monday, an IBA press conference descended into farce as controversial president Umar Kremlev made baseless claims about Lin and Khelif and launched an astonishing tirade against IOC president Thomas Bach.\n\nKhelif and Lin were allowed to return to competition by the IOC, which is effectively administering the Paris 2024 boxing tournament in the IBA's absence.\n\nThe case has aroused global interest, with figures such as former United States president Donald Trump and Harry Potter author JK Rowling weighing in on the issue.\n\nKhelif won every round on the judges' cards, appearing close to securing a stoppage I know I'm a talented person and this is a gift to all Algerians.\"\n\nChants of \"Imane\" tumbled down from the stands as Khelif, who is one of two boxers caught up in the ongoing row, dominated Suwannapheng to confirm she will get the chance to emulate compatriot Hocine Soltani, who won lightweight gold in 1996.\n\nThe participation of Khelif and Chinese Taipei featherweight Lin Yu-ting has caused an international storm since Khelif beat Angela Carini of Italy in just 46 seconds in her opening bout last Thursday.\n\nBoth Khelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association (IBA) during last year's World Championships for failing to meet gender eligibility criteria.\n\nHowever, the IBA, which was was expelled by the International Olympic Commitee (IOC) over financial and corruption concerns, has failed to provide any proof of its findings.\n\nOn Monday, an IBA press conference descended into farce as controversial president Umar Kremlev made baseless claims about Lin and Khelif and launched an astonishing tirade against IOC president Thomas Bach.\n\nKhelif and Lin were allowed to return to competition by the IOC, which is effectively administering the Paris 2024 boxing tournament in the IBA's absence.\n\nThe case has aroused global interest, with figures such as former United States president Donald Trump and Harry Potter author JK Rowling {"uri": "8262504734", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:54:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:54:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:51:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-13716199/Algerian-boxer-Olympic-gender-row-marches-final.html", "title": "Algerian boxer in Olympic gender row marches into final", "body": "Final chance: Algeria's Imane Khelif reacts after beating Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng\n\nThe Algerian boxer embroiled in a major gender controversy at the Paris Olympics won her semi-final on Tuesday to guarantee at least a silver medal in front of a raucous Roland Garros crowd that chanted her name.\n\nImane Khelif defeated Thailand's 2023 world silver medallist Janjaem Suwannapheng in a unanimous points decision to march into Friday's final in the women's 66kg category.\n\nTaiwan's Lin Yu-ting, the other boxer in the eye of a storm over her eligibility, is herself sure to take home at least bronze at a different weight.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif and Lin both fought at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago but there was no controversy at the time and neither won a medal.\n\nBoth were disqualified from last year's world championships after failing gender eligibility tests, but were cleared to compete in Paris.\n\nKhelif was given the biggest roar of the night as she entered the arena at Roland Garros, usually home to Grand Slam tennis but hosting Olympic boxing and a sizeable number of Algerian fans with flags.\n\nCries of \"Imane, Imane\" rang out repeatedly before and during the bout.\n\nThe Thai, who had a clear height disadvantage, took a standing count in the third round after feeling the full power of the superior Algerian.\n\nAt the end of the fight at the 15,000-seated Court Philippe-Chatrier, which was close to capacity, the two fighters greeted each other warmly and shook hands.\n\nKhelif did a dance in the middle of the ring, to more roars of approval.\n\nKhelif faces China's Yang Liu or Taiwan's Chen Nien-chin for gold.\n\nThe gender controversy ignited when Khelif defeated Angela Carini in 46 seconds in her opening bout in the French capital, the Italian reduced to tears and abandoning the fight after suffering a badly hurt nose.\n\nThe 2023 world championships, from which Lin and Khelif were expelled, were run by the International Boxing Association (IBA) but the International Olympic Committee (IOC) is organising the sport at the Games because of financial, governance and ethical concerns at the IBA.\n\nThe IBA's Kremlin-linked president Umar Kremlev claimed at a chaotic press conference on Monday that both fighters had \"genetic testing that shows that these are men\".\n\nThe IOC has leapt to the defence of Khelif and Lin, with president Thomas Bach saying they were born and raised as women, and have passports saying that.\n\nThe 28-year-old Lin fights in the semi-finals of the women's 57kg division on Wednesday.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imane_Khelif", "type": "wiki",
