{"uri": "8262491678", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:36:48", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:36:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:35:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.daytondailynews.com/nation-world/boxer-imane-khelif-advances-to-gold-medal-bout-with-another-victory-amid-gender-misconceptions/4HI6KSDVQZCQFE463IGOFWE43M/", "title": "Boxer Imane Khelif advances to gold-medal bout with another victory amid gender misconceptions", "body": "With one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal and its first in women's boxing.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared for her and chanted her name repeatedly during her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday against Yang Liu of China.\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nShe then controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing 8-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches. Khelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris.\n\nAfter hugging Suwannapheng, Khelif celebrated in the ring, running joyously in place while pumping her fists as the crowd roared for her again. Khelif received her post-fight medical check and was headed out of the arena when she was mobbed by fans near the exit. They hugged Khelif, demanded selfies and waved Algerian flags while she made her way backstage.\n\nThe ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the center of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender.\n\nIn an interview with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nKhelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal -- and now she's one win away.\n\nKhelif entered the ring against Suwannapheng to cheers echoing through the famed tennis arena. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose stigmatization by the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association has been taken very personally in her country.\n\nBoth fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.\n\nThe fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing 8-count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary -- as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif is on the best run of her amateur career at the Olympics. She has performed solidly at the international level and even won some regional tournaments, but Khelif has never been a dominant fighter on the world stage until her two strong performances -- and 46 seconds of easy work against a third -- to reach the final in Paris.\n\nThe IOC and its president, Thomas Bach, have repeatedly defended the Olympic eligibility of Khelif and fellow boxer Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan while condemning the IBA as incompetent and biased.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the IBA in the middle of last year's world championships over what it claimed were failed eligibility tests for the women's competition. The IBA has been banished from the Olympics since before the Tokyo Games, and the body struggled to articulate the reasoning for its decisions on Khelif and Lin at a news conference Monday.\n\nLin also has clinched a medal and advanced to the Olympic semifinals. She fights Esra Yildiz Kahraman of Turkey in the first bout Wednesday night at Roland Garros.\n\nAlgeria's Olympic team has reacted forcefully to the criticism and negative attention around Khelif, and the fan turnout in Roland Garros reflected the seriousness with which the accusations have been received in her home country and in its French diaspora.\n\nChinese Taipei has reacted with equal condemnation of the IBA's claims and the worldwide swirl of scrutiny. Sports officials on Tuesday said they are considering legal action against the IBA after sending a letter protesting \"the International Boxing Association's continued publication of false information, obscuring the facts, and attempting to interfere with the normal conduct of the event regardless of the rights and interests of athletes.\"", "source": {"uri": "daytondailynews.com", {"uri": "8262531821", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:22:55", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:22:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T22:20:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.rappler.com/sports/boxing/imane-khelif-reaches-boxing-final-amid-gender-row-paris-olympics-2024/", "title": "Algeria's Imane Khelif reaches Olympic boxing final amid gender row", "body": "PARIS, France - Algeria's Imane Khelif, the boxer at the center of a gender dispute, beat Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng by unanimous decision in the women's 66kg semifinals in the Paris Olympics on Tuesday, August 6 (Wednesday, August 7 Manila time), to progress to the gold-medal match at Roland Garros.\n\nKhelif, a silver medalist in the 2022 World Championships, and Taiwanese boxer Lin Yu-ting have been in the spotlight at the Olympics as part of a storm that has dominated headlines and been the subject of much discussion on social media platforms.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association from the 2023 World Championships in New Delhi, India, with the body saying in a shambolic press conference on Monday, August 5, that a sex chromosome test had ruled both of them ineligible.\n\nAt those World Championships, Khelif beat Suwannapheng by unanimous decision in the semifinals before being disqualified. Suwannapheng competed in the final after Khelif's disqualification and won silver.\n\nKhelif and Lin are competing in the Olympics after the International Olympic Committee stripped the IBA of its status as the sport's governing body in 2023 and took control of organizing the boxing in Paris.\n\nThe IOC has rejected the results of the IBA-ordered tests as arbitrary and illegitimate, saying there was no reason to conduct them.\n\nAt these Games, the IOC is using boxing eligibility rules that were applied in the 2016 and 2021 Olympics, which do not include gender testing.\n\nAlgerian fans flocked into a repurposed Court Philippe Chatrier, devoid of its iconic red clay, looking to support Khelif and screamed \"Imane, Imane, Imane\" ahead of the bout, while also booing Suwannapheng on entry.\n\nIn a cautious first round, both boxers attempted to keep their distance and engaged sparingly, but Khelif used her jab to better effect than her Thai opponent.\n\nSuwannapheng connected with a big right hand in the second, but the rangy Algerian's excellent technique allowed her to keep landing shots and sweep the judges' scorecards.\n\nKhelif threw caution to the wind and went after Suwannapheng in the final round, peppering her with jarring shots to claim the win by unanimous decision.\n\nBoth boxers touched gloves in a sign of respect after the fight, and when Khelif was announced as winner, a deafening roar erupted from the fans in attendance.\n\nKhelif waited until her opponent left the ring before celebrating, jogging on the spot with an enormous grin on her face before leaving and shadow-boxing her way to the doctor's station for a quick medical check.\n\nKhelif will face Yang Liu of China in the final on Friday, August 9.\n\nLin also reached the semifinals in the featherweight category, where she will take on Turkey's Esra Yildiz on Wednesday.\n\nThe storm surrounding Khelif and Lin erupted when the Algerian's opponent Angela Carini pulled out of their round of 16 bout last week after just 46 seconds, saying she felt intense pain and feared for her safety after being hit with a barrage of punches.\n\nIn the aftermath of Carini's withdrawal, the gender furore swept social media, with people such as Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling and Tesla founder Elon Musk voicing their opposition to the two boxers competing at the Games.\n\nFollowing the bout, Italian Carini apologized to Khelif and said she did not harbor any ill feeling toward the Algerian. - Rappler.com", "source": {"uri": "rappler.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rappler"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imane_Khelif", I know I'm a talented person and this is a gift to all Algerians.\"\n\nChants of \"Imane\" tumbled down from the stands as Khelif, who is one of two boxers caught up in the ongoing row, dominated Suwannapheng to confirm she will get the chance to emulate compatriot Hocine Soltani, who won lightweight gold in 1996.\n\nThe participation of Khelif and Chinese Taipei featherweight Lin Yu-ting has caused an international storm since Khelif beat Angela Carini of Italy in just 46 seconds in her opening bout last Thursday.\n\nBoth Khelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association (IBA) during last year's World Championships for failing to meet gender eligibility criteria.\n\nHowever, the IBA, which was was expelled by the International Olympic Commitee (IOC) over financial and corruption concerns, has failed to provide any proof of its findings.\n\nOn Monday, an IBA press conference descended into farce as controversial president Umar Kremlev made baseless claims about Lin and Khelif and launched an astonishing tirade against IOC president Thomas Bach.\n\nKhelif and Lin were allowed to return to competition by the IOC, which is effectively administering the Paris 2024 boxing tournament in the IBA's absence.\n\nThe case has aroused global interest, with figures such as former United States president Donald Trump and Harry Potter author JK Rowling weighing in on the issue.\n\nKhelif won every round on the judges' cards, appearing close to securing a stoppage at times, and celebrated with a victory jig in the ring as the Algerian supporters {"uri": "8262664050", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "01:10:51", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T01:10:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T01:08:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/sports/olympics/imane-khelif-to-fight-for-gold-algerian-boxer-in-paris-olympics-gender-row-marches-into-final-101722991771293.html", "title": "Imane Khelif to fight for gold: Algerian boxer in Paris Olympics gender row marches into final", "body": "The Algerian boxer embroiled in a major gender controversy at the Paris Olympics won her semi-final on Tuesday to guarantee at least a silver medal in front of a raucous Roland Garros crowd that chanted her name.\n\nImane Khelif defeated Thailand's 2023 world silver medallist Janjaem Suwannapheng in a unanimous points decision to march into Friday's final in the women's 66kg category.\n\n\"I am like all athletes, I am here to achieve my dream,\" Khelif told AFP afterwards.\n\nTaiwan's Lin Yu-ting, the other boxer in the eye of a storm over her eligibility, is herself sure to take home at least bronze at a different weight.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif and Lin both fought at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago but there was no controversy at the time and neither won a medal.\n\nBoth were disqualified from last year's world championships after failing gender eligibility tests, but were cleared to compete in Paris.\n\nKhelif was given the biggest roar of the night as she entered the arena at Roland Garros, usually home to Grand Slam tennis but hosting Olympic boxing and a sizeable number of Algerian fans with flags.\n\nCries of \"Imane, Imane\" rang out repeatedly before and during the bout.\n\nThe Thai Janjaem, who had a clear height disadvantage, took a standing count in the third round after feeling the full power of the superior Algerian.\n\nAt the end of the fight at the 15,000-seated Court Philippe-Chatrier, which was close to capacity, the two fighters greeted each other warmly and shook hands.\n\nKhelif did a dance in the middle of the ring, to more roars of approval.\n\nShe faces Yang Liu for gold after the Chinese boxer beat Taiwan's Chen Nien-chin in the other semi-final on points.\n\n\"I am focusing on the competition and other things are not important. The important thing is that I am in the final now,\" Khelif told BeIN Sports.\n\n\"I am very proud of this new achievement. I gave everything I had. We worked as a team for years and the dream has become a reality.\n\n\"I hope to focus and be up to the responsibility in the dream final.\"\n\nThe beaten Thai moved to play down the furore.\n\n\"I had heard about the news regarding her, but I wasn't following it closely,\" she said. \"She is a woman, but she is very strong.\"\n\nThe gender controversy ignited when Khelif defeated Angela Carini in 46 seconds in her opening bout in the French capital, the Italian reduced to tears and abandoning the fight after suffering a badly hurt nose.\n\nThe 2023 world championships, from which Lin and Khelif were expelled, were run by the International Boxing Association (IBA) but the International Olympic Committee (IOC) is organising the sport at the Games because of financial, governance and ethical concerns at the IBA.\n\nThe IBA's Kremlin-linked president Umar Kremlev claimed at a chaotic press conference on Monday that both fighters had \"genetic testing that shows that these are men\".\n\nThe IOC has leapt to the defence of Khelif and Lin, with president Thomas Bach saying they were born and raised as women, and have passports saying that.\n\nThe 28-year-old Lin fights in the semi-finals of the women's 57kg division on Wednesday.", "source": {"uri": "hindustantimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hindustan Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": But she praised her opponent and thanked her supporters.\n\nKhelif said: 'She was very good but I trained for two weeks and watched videos of how she fights.\n\n'I am one step from gold. Thank you to all the people who have stood by me especially the people of Algeria.'\n\nThe controversy surrounding Khelif exploded into a huge row after she beat her Italian opponent Angela Carini in just 46 seconds when Carini quit the match and sank to her knees in tears, declaring; 'it's just not fair.'\n\nThe Italian stoked claims that the Algerian is not a woman.\n\nBut Khelif was also reduced to tears after her last fight, against Hungarian Anna Luca Hamori, when she shouted from the ring; 'I am a woman.'\n\nTonight supporters of the 25-year-old welter-weight from rural Algeria offered her their unflinching support amid the bad-tempered gender row.\n\nAlgeria's Imane Khelif cools off while fighting Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng in their women's 66 kg semifinal boxing match\n\nImane Khelif takes a blow to the face from Janjaem Suwannapheng during the Women's 66Kg boxing semifinal\n\nImane Khelif of Algeria in action against Janjaem Suwannapheng\n\nAnna Azout, 26, a lawyer, told MailOnline: 'Khelif has been terribly mistreated. She is the victim of both sexism and racism. Some people in France just do not want women, particularly foreign women not to succeed.'\n\nNariman, 50, a company director, who had come to watch the fight with her son Ramy Auzmann, 16, said: 'Khelif has been treated very badly.\n\n'She is an athlete who just wants to participate in her sport and do the best she can. {"uri": "8262504709", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:07:52", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:07:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:51:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13716185/Olympics-Boxing-Algerian-Khelif-wins-semi-final-amid-gender-dispute.html", "title": "Olympics-Boxing-Algerian Khelif wins women's semi-final amid gender...", "body": "By Julien Pretot and Aadi Nair\n\nPARIS, Aug 6 (Reuters) - Imane Khelif, the boxer at the centre of a gender dispute, beat Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng by unanimous decision in a welterweight semi-final fight at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday to progress to the women's final at Roland Garros.\n\nKhelif, a silver medallist at the 2022 worlds, and Taiwanese boxer Lin Yu-ting have been in the spotlight at the Olympics as part of a storm that has dominated headlines and been the subject of much discussion on social media platforms.\n\n\"I don\u00b4t want anything to be said about the controversy,\" Khelif said after her win.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association from the 2023 World Championships in New Delhi, with the body saying in a shambolic press conference on Monday that a sex chromosome test had ruled both of them ineligible.\n\nAt those World Championships, Khelif beat Suwannapheng by unanimous decision in the semi-finals before being disqualified. Suwannapheng competed in the final after Khelif's disqualification and won silver.\n\nKhelif and Lin are competing in the Olympics after the International Olympic Committee stripped the IBA of its status as the sport's governing body in 2023 and took control of organising the boxing in Paris.\n\nThe IOC has rejected the results of the IBA-ordered tests as arbitrary and illegitimate, saying there was no reason to conduct them.\n\nAt these Games, the IOC is using boxing eligibility rules that were applied at the 2016 and 2021 Olympics which do not include gender testing.\n\nFAN SUPPORT\n\nAlgerian fans flocked into a repurposed Court Philippe Chatrier, devoid of its iconic red clay, looking to support Khelif and screamed \"Imane, Imane, Imane\" ahead of the bout, while also booing Suwannapheng on entry.\n\nIn a cautious first round, both boxers attempted to keep their distance and engaged sparingly, but Khelif used her jab to better effect than her Thai opponent.\n\nSuwannapheng connected with a big right hand in the second, but the rangy Algerian's excellent technique allowed her to keep landing shots and sweep the judge's scorecards.\n\nKhelif threw caution to the wind and went after Suwannapheng in the final round, peppering her with jarring shots to claim the win by unanimous decision.\n\nBoth boxers touched gloves in a sign of respect after the fight, and when Khelif was announced as winner a deafening roar erupted from the fans in attendance.\n\n\"I just had the performance I was looking to deliver today to make the fans happy,\" Khelif said.\n\nKhelif waited until her opponent left the ring before celebrating, jogging on the spot with an enormous grin on her face before leaving and shadow-boxing her way to the doctor's station for a quick medical check.\n\n\"I have not followed the controversy closely but all I know is that she is a woman and she is a strong fighter,\" Suwannapheng said.\n\nKhelif will face Yang Liu of China in the final on Friday.\n\nLin also reached the semi-finals in the featherweight category, where she will take on Turkey's Esra Yildiz on Wednesday.\n\nThe storm surrounding Khelif and Lin erupted when the Algerian's opponent Angela Carini pulled out of their round-of-16 bout last week after just 46 seconds, saying she felt intense pain and feared for her safety after being hit with a barrage of punches.\n\nIn the aftermath of Carini's withdrawal, the gender furore swept social media, with people such as Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling and Tesla founder Elon Musk voicing their opposition to the two boxers competing at the Games.\n\nFollowing the bout, Italian Carini apologised to Khelif and said she did not harbour any ill feeling toward the Algerian.\n\n(Reporting by Julien Pretot, Philip O'Connor, Ashraf Hamed Atta, Layli Foroudi and Aadi Nair in Paris; Editing by Toby Davis and Bill Berkrot)", "source": {"uri": row marches into final", "body": "Paris (AFP) - The Algerian boxer embroiled in a major gender controversy at the Paris Olympics won her semi-final on Tuesday to guarantee at least a silver medal in front of a raucous Roland Garros crowd that chanted her name.\n\nImane Khelif defeated Thailand's 2023 world silver medallist Janjaem Suwannapheng in a unanimous points decision to march into Friday's final in the women's 66kg category.\n\nTaiwan's Lin Yu-ting, the other boxer in the eye of a storm over her eligibility, is herself sure to take home at least bronze at a different weight.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif and Lin both fought at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago but there was no controversy at the time and neither won a medal.\n\nBoth were disqualified from last year's world championships after failing gender eligibility tests, but were cleared to compete in Paris.\n\nKhelif was given the biggest roar of the night as she entered the arena at Roland Garros, usually home to Grand Slam tennis but hosting Olympic boxing and a sizeable number of Algerian fans with flags.\n\nCries of \"Imane, Imane\" rang out repeatedly before and during the bout.\n\nThe Thai Janjaem, who had a clear height disadvantage, took a standing count in the third round after feeling the full power of the superior Algerian.\n\nAt the end of the fight at the 15,000-seated Court Philippe-Chatrier, which was close to capacity, the two fighters greeted each other warmly and shook hands.\n\nKhelif did a dance in the middle of the ring, to more roars of approval.\n\nShe faces Yang Liu for gold after the Chinese boxer beat Taiwan's Chen Nien-chin in the other semi-final on points.\n\nThe gender controversy ignited when Khelif defeated Angela Carini in 46 seconds in her opening bout in the French capital, the Italian reduced to tears and abandoning the fight after suffering a badly hurt nose.\n\nThe 2023 world championships, from which Lin and Khelif were expelled, were run by the International Boxing Association (IBA) but the International Olympic Committee (IOC) is organising the sport at the Games because of financial, governance and ethical concerns at the IBA.\n\nThe IBA's Kremlin-linked president Umar Kremlev claimed at a chaotic press conference on Monday that both fighters had \"genetic testing that shows that these are men\".\n\nThe IOC has leapt to the defence of Khelif and Lin, with president Thomas Bach saying they were born and raised as women, and have passports saying that.\n\nThe 28-year-old Lin fights in the semi-finals of the women's saying - Imane Khelif sidesteps gender row", "body": "The Algerian 66kg finalist and fellow boxer Lin Yu-ting of Chinese Taipei were previously ruled ineligible by the International Boxing Association.\n\nImane Khelif says she \"doesn't care\" about the controversy swirling over her inclusion in the women's 66kg boxing category at the Paris Olympics after storming into the gold medal match with a unanimous points win over Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand.\n\nHundreds of flag-waving Algerian supporters turned the normally genteel surroundings of Phillippe-Chatrier Court at Roland Garros into a cauldron of noise in support of Khelif, who is at the centre of a gender eligibility row.\n\nHaving avoided the huge media scrum after her previous bouts, Khelif broke her silence to maintain: \"I don't care what anyone is saying about me with the controversy.\n\nChants of \"Imane\" tumbled down from the stands as Khelif, who is one of two boxers caught up in the ongoing row, dominated Suwannapheng to confirm she will get the chance to emulate compatriot Hocine Soltani, who won lightweight gold in 1996.\n\nThe participation of Khelif and Chinese Taipei featherweight Lin Yu-ting has caused an international storm since Khelif beat Angela Carini of Italy in just 46 seconds in her opening bout last Thursday.\n\nBoth Khelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association (IBA) during last year's World Championships for failing to meet gender eligibility criteria.\n\nHowever, the IBA, which was was expelled by the International Olympic Commitee (IOC) over financial and corruption concerns, has failed to provide any proof of its findings.\n\nKhelif and Lin were allowed to return to competition by the IOC, which is effectively administering the Paris 2024 boxing tournament in the IBA's absence.\n\nThe case has aroused global interest, with figures such as former United States president Donald Trump and Harry Potter author JK Rowling weighing in on the issue.\n\nKhelif won every round on the judges' cards, appearing close to securing a stoppage at times, and celebrated with a victory jig in the ring as the Algerian supporters celebrated {"uri": "8262517654", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:06:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:06:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T22:05:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.namibian.com.na/algerian-boxer-in-paris-olympics-gender-row-marches-into-final/", "title": "Algerian boxer in Paris Olympics gender row marches into final", "body": "The Algerian boxer embroiled in a major gender controversy at the Paris Olympics won her semi-final on Tuesday to guarantee at least a silver medal in front of a raucous Roland Garros crowd that chanted her name.\n\nImane Khelif defeated Thailand's 2023 world silver medallist Janjaem Suwannapheng in a unanimous points decision to march into Friday's final in the women's 66kg category.\n\nTaiwan's Lin Yu-ting, the other boxer in the eye of a storm over her eligibility, is herself sure to take home at least bronze at a different weight.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif and Lin both fought at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago but there was no controversy at the time and neither won a medal.\n\nBoth were disqualified from last year's world championships after failing gender eligibility tests, but were cleared to compete in Paris.\n\n\"I am focusing on the competition and other things are not important. The important thing is that I am in the final now,\" Khelif told BeIN Sports.\n\n\"I am very proud of this new achievement. I gave everything I had. We worked as a team for years and the dream has become a reality. I hope to focus and be up to the responsibility in the dream final.\"\n\nKhelif was given the biggest roar of the night as she entered the arena at Roland Garros, usually home to Grand Slam tennis but hosting Olympic boxing and a sizeable number of Algerian fans with flags.\n\nCries of \"Imane, Imane\" rang out repeatedly before and during the bout.\n\nThe Thai Janjaem, who had a clear height disadvantage, took a standing count in the third round after feeling the full power of the superior Algerian.\n\nAt the end of the fight at the 15,000-seated Court Philippe-Chatrier, which was close to capacity, the two fighters greeted each other warmly and shook hands.\n\nKhelif did a dance in the middle of the ring, to more roars of approval.\n\nShe faces Yang Liu for gold after the Chinese boxer beat Taiwan's Chen Nien-chin in the other semi-final on points.\n\nThe gender controversy ignited when Khelif defeated Angela Carini in 46 seconds in her opening bout in the French capital, the Italian reduced to tears and abandoning the fight after suffering a badly hurt nose.\n\nThe 2023 world championships, from which Lin and Khelif were expelled, were run by the International Boxing Association (IBA) but the International Olympic Committee (IOC) is organising the sport at the Games because of financial, governance and ethical concerns at the IBA.\n\nThe IBA's Kremlin-linked president Umar Kremlev claimed at a chaotic press conference on Monday that both fighters had \"genetic testing that shows that these are men\".\n\nThe IOC has leapt to the defence of Khelif and Lin, with president Thomas Bach saying they were born and raised as women, and have passports saying that.\n\nThe 28-year-old Lin fights in the semi-finals of the women's 57kg division on Wednesday.", {"uri": "8262497067", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:42:50", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:42:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:42:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.straitstimes.com/sport/boxing-algerian-khelif-wins-semi-final-amid-gender-dispute", "title": "Boxing-Algerian Khelif wins women's semi-final amid gender dispute", "body": "PARIS - Imane Khelif, the boxer at the centre of a gender dispute, beat Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng by unanimous decision in a welterweight semi-final fight at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday to progress to the women's final at Roland Garros.\n\nKhelif, a silver medallist at the 2022 worlds, and Taiwanese boxer Lin Yu-ting have been in the spotlight at the Olympics as part of a storm that has dominated headlines and been the subject of much discussion on social media platforms.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association from the 2023 World Championships in New Delhi, with the body saying in a shambolic press conference on Monday that a sex chromosome test had ruled both of them ineligible.\n\nAt those World Championships, Khelif beat Suwannapheng by unanimous decision in the semi-finals before being disqualified. Suwannapheng competed in the final after Khelif's disqualification and won silver.\n\nKhelif and Lin are competing in the Olympics after the International Olympic Committee stripped the IBA of its status as the sport's governing body in 2023 and took control of organising the boxing in Paris.\n\nThe IOC has rejected the results of the IBA-ordered tests as arbitrary and illegitimate, saying there was no reason to conduct them.\n\nAt these Games, the IOC is using boxing eligibility rules that were applied at the 2016 and 2021 Olympics which do not include gender testing.\n\nFAN SUPPORT\n\nAlgerian fans flocked into a repurposed Court Philippe Chatrier, devoid of its iconic red clay, looking to support Khelif and screamed \"Imane, Imane, Imane\" ahead of the bout, while also booing Suwannapheng on entry.\n\nIn a cautious first round, both boxers attempted to keep their distance and engaged sparingly, but Khelif used her jab to better effect than her Thai opponent.\n\nSuwannapheng connected with a big right hand in the second, but the rangy Algerian's excellent technique allowed her to keep landing shots and sweep the judge's scorecards.\n\nKhelif threw caution to the wind and went after Suwannapheng in the final round, peppering her with jarring shots to claim the win by unanimous decision.\n\nBoth boxers touched gloves in a sign of respect after the fight, and when Khelif was announced as winner a deafening roar erupted from the fans in attendance.\n\nKhelif waited until her opponent left the ring before celebrating, jogging on the spot with an enormous grin on her face before leaving and shadow-boxing her way to the doctor's station for a quick medical check.\n\nKhelif will face Yang Liu of China in the final on Friday.\n\nLin also reached the semi-finals in the featherweight category, where she will take on Turkey's Esra Yildiz on Wednesday.\n\nThe storm surrounding Khelif and Lin erupted when the Algerian's opponent Angela Carini pulled out of their round-of-16 bout last week after just 46 seconds, saying she felt intense pain and feared for her safety after being hit with a barrage of punches.\n\nIn the aftermath of Carini's withdrawal, the gender furore swept social media, with people such as Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling and Tesla founder Elon Musk voicing their opposition to the two boxers competing at the Games.\n\nFollowing the bout, Italian Carini apologised to Khelif and said she did not harbour any ill feeling toward the Algerian. The fight is scheduled for three 3-minute rounds.\n\nKhelif, 25, is a fleet-footed technician with a consistent jab and a right hand that keeps her opponents honest. In addition to overcoming three fighters in the 66kg category, the Algerian boxer has also had to contend with a huge gender row that erupted last week on social media.\n\nMORE: Who is Imane Khelif? Bio and history of Algerian Olympic boxer\n\n\"There is a mental health team that doesn't let us follow social media, especially in the Olympic Games, whether me or other athletes. I'm here to compete and get a good result,\" Khelif told SNTV via The Metro.\n\n\"I send a message to all the people of the world to uphold the Olympic principles and the Olympic Charter to refrain from bullying all athletes because this has massive effects. It can destroy people, it can kill people's thoughts, spirit and mind. It can divide people. And because of that, I ask them to refrain from bullying.\"\n\nMORE: IBA endangers Olympic boxing's future | Imane's latest opponent bigger than her sport\n\nThe 23-year-old Suwannapheng advanced to the semifinal stages thanks to a points win over Turkey's Busenaz Surmeneli. Like Khelif, she is confident of victory and that's despite suffering a pair of losses to the Algerian boxer last year.\n\n\"I've improved since then and I'll fight with all I've got,\" said Suwannapheng in an interview with Thai newspaper Khaosod.\n\n\"I'm not afraid because we're evenly matched. final", "body": "Algerian fans celebrate as Imane Khelif books place in women's 66kg final\n\nMark Staniforth, PA Olympics Correspondent, Paris\n\n6 August 2024 at 11:13 pm\n\nHundreds of flag-waving Algerian supporters turned the normally genteel surroundings of Phillippe-Chatrier Court at Roland Garros into a cauldron of noise as boxer Imane Khelif sealed her place in the Olympic women's welterweight final.\n\nChants of \"Imane\" tumbled down from the stands as Khelif, who is one of two boxers at the centre of a gender eligibility row, dominated her opponent Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand to confirm she will get the chance to emulate compatriot Hocine Soltani, who won lightweight gold in 1996.\n\nThe participation of Khelif and Chinese Taipei featherweight Lin Yu-ting has caused an international storm since Khelif beat Angela Carini of Italy in just 46 seconds in her opening bout last Thursday.\n\nBoth Khelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association (IBA) during last year's World Championships for failing to meet gender eligibility criteria.\n\nHowever, the IBA, which was was expelled by the International Olympic Commitee (IOC) over financial and corruption concerns, has failed to provide any proof of its findings.\n\nOn Monday, an IBA press conference descended into farce as controversial president Umar Kremlev made baseless claims about Lin and Khelif and launched an astonishing tirade against IOC president Thomas Bach.\n\nKhelif and Lin were allowed to return to competition by the IOC, which is effectively administering the Paris 2024 boxing tournament in the IBA's absence.\n\nThe case has aroused global interest, with figures such as former United States president Donald Trump and Harry Potter author JK Rowling weighing in on the issue.\n\nKhelif won every round on the judges' cards, appearing close to securing a stoppage at times, and celebrated with a victory jig in the ring as the Algerian supporters Controversial Algerian Gender-row Boxer Imane Khelif Storms Into Olympic Boxing Final After Dismantling Her Thai Opponent In Front Of Deafening Crowd - Ny Breaking News", "body": "Controversial gender-conflict boxer Imane Khelif has made boxing history tonight by winning an Olympic gold medal.\n\nThe 25-year-old Algerian was at the centre of the biggest controversy of the Paris 2024 Games after she was allowed to compete at the Olympics despite having previously been disqualified for failing a gender test.\n\nBut she overcame enormous public pressure - not least from the discredited International Boxing Association, which had barred her from competing - to battle her way to the final after beating Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng at the Rolan Garros tennis stadium, which has been converted into a boxing arena.\n\nAfter the referee raised her hand to acknowledge her victory, she danced around the ring with unbridled joy.\n\nIf Khelif reaches the podium, she will be the first Algerian woman to win a medal in boxing at the Olympic Games.\n\nImane Khalif punches Janjaem Suwannapheng in the face during the semi-final of the women's 66kg boxing event at the 2014 Paris Olympics\n\nKhalif was crowned the winner of the match against Suwannapheng at the Rolan Garros tennis stadium which has been converted into a boxing arena\n\nAfter the referee raised her hand in victory, she danced around the ring with unbridled joy\n\nAfter the fight, Khelif refused to discuss the gender controversy surrounding her, but praised her opponent and thanked her supporters.\n\nKhelif said: 'She was very good, but I trained for two weeks and watched videos of her fighting skills.\n\n\"I am just one step away from gold. Thanks to all the people who supported me, especially the people of Algeria.\"\n\nThe controversy surrounding Khelif erupted into a major brawl after she defeated her Italian opponent Angela Carini in just 46 seconds. Carini conceded the match, falling to her knees in tears and shouting, \"It's just not fair.\"\n\nThe Italian propagandist claims that the Algerian is not a woman.\n\nBut Khelif also burst into tears after her last fight, against Hungary's Anna Luca Hamori, when she shouted from the ring: \"I am a woman.\"\n\nTonight, supporters of the 25-year-old heavyweight from the Algerian countryside gave her their unwavering support, despite the raging gender feud.\n\nAlgeria's Imane Khelif cools down during a fight with Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng in their women's 66kg boxing semi-final match\n\nImane Khelif takes a punch in the face from Janjaem Suwannapheng during the women's 66kg boxing semi-final\n\nAlgeria's Imane Khelif in action against Janjaem Suwannapheng\n\nAnna Azout, 26, a lawyer, told MailOnline: 'Khelif has been terribly abused. She is a victim of both sexism and racism. Some people in France just don't want women, especially foreign women, to be unsuccessful.'\n\nNariman, 50, the company's director, who came to the fight with her son Ramy Auzmann, 16, said: 'Khelif has been treated very badly.\n\n\"She's an athlete who just wants to play her sport and do her best. But she's turned into a political pawn.\"\n\nOther supporters were seated in many places in the intimate boxing arena.\n\nWaving the green and white flag with the red crescent and star, the crowd jumped to their feet and cheered as Imane Khelif entered the arena.\n\nAnd they chanted, \"Khelif, Khelif\" as she entered the boxing ring and took the blue corner.\n\nReferee Shawn Reese raises Imane {"uri": "8262463714", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:09:04", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:09:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:07:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/paris-olympics-imane-khelif-moves-on-to-gold-medal-bout-with-another-unanimous-victory-210354375.html", "title": "Paris Olympics: Imane Khelif moves on to gold medal bout with another unanimous victory", "body": "PARIS -- The story of the Olympics' boxing gender controversy moved to a grander stage on Tuesday night, as Algeria's Imane Khelif won a unanimous decision and now moves on to fight for an Olympic gold medal.\n\nKhelif squared off against Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng shortly after 10:30 p.m. under the closed roof of Roland-Garros Stadium, before a raucous and engaged crowd. The echoes in cavernous Roland-Garros were far louder than tiny North Paris Arena, where Khelif's Olympic journey began.\n\nAlgerian flags lined Roland-Garros' lower sections, and Khelif entered the arena second, to the night's loudest cheers and deafening chants of \"I-MANE.\" Wearing blue trunks and top, she stormed into the arena, punching the air. Khelif and Suwannapheng tapped gloves at the center of the ring, and the fight began.\n\nIn Round 1, Khelif once again used her reach advantage, keeping Suwannapheng at a distance before landing jabs. Suwannapheng spent much of the early part of the round in a defensive crouch, and the crowd, sensing her conservatism, tried to rally Khelif with loud chants of \"I-MANE.\" With just over a minute remaining in the round, Khelif charged in and caught Suwannapheng in a clinch, forcing the referee to step in and break up the pair. Khelif won the first round 10-9 on all five judges' cards.\n\nRound 2 began with Khelif again taking the fight to Suwannapheng, but this time Suwannapheng fought back, charging inside Khelif's reach to land a few early blows. Seventy-five seconds into the round, Khelif caught Suwannapheng with a hard uppercut that seemed to stagger her. Suwannapheng's counterpunches became wilder, most failing to land. The two again tapped gloves as the round ended. Khelif again won the round 10-9 on all cards.\n\nIn the final round, Suwannapheng took an aggressive tack right from the start, appearing to stagger Khelif while also clutching at her. Khelif landed some powerful roundhouse blows to the side of Suwannapheng's head, and even lost her balance in her aggressive attack. Referee Shawn Reese of the United States let the fighters clinch, and as the seconds wound down, Khelif used the maneuver to sap Suwannapheng's energy. Knowing she needed a knockout, Suwannapheng charged straight into Khelif's jabs. But it wasn't enough, and the judges gave Khelif another 10-9 win as the crowd roared. Khelif danced and grinned in the middle of the ring, to the delight of the crowd.\n\nKhelif and Chinese Taipei's Lin Yu-ting, who is scheduled to fight tomorrow night in the 57kg semifinals,, stand at the center of a complex controversy over gender and eligibility, a story fraught with politics, bureaucracy, misinformation and varying applications of science. Khelif has been in the world's spotlight ever since her first bout last Thursday, when her opponent, Italy's Angela Carini, tapped out after just 46 seconds.\n\nCarini tearfully complained after the fight that Khelif's punches were too hard. That charge quickly sparked a worldwide firestorm as Khelif and Lin had failed gender qualification tests administered by the International Boxing Association in 2022 and 2023. In a coincidental reunion, Khelif had beaten Suwannapheng, Tuesday night's Olympic opponent, in the semifinals of the 2023 world championships before being disqualified by the IBA.\n\nHowever, since the International Olympic Committee had severed ties with the IBA and no longer recognizes it as a legitimate boxing authority, the tests did not come into play when determining the boxers' eligibility for these Olympics. Instead, in the absence of any independent regulatory authority, the IOC dismissed the IBA's tests out of hand and instead relied on the boxers' passports to determine their gender eligibility. Both boxers were born female and have lived as females their entire lives, and the IOC has maintained that this is the only necessary metric for judging their qualifications.\n\nThe IBA attempted to explain the specifics of its tests and the rationale behind them in a hastily-called Monday press conference, but any useful information the organization could have shared was drowned out by a chaotic cascade of grievances and rants against the IOC. Meanwhile, the IOC has insisted that the matter is a closed one for these Games, but has allowed that the passport-based system of gender qualification for boxing could be reconsidered in years to come.\n\nKhelif now moves on to the gold medal match, scheduled for Friday evening at 10:51 Paris time. Lin will fight Wednesday night in the 57kg semifinal round. Both have clinched at least bronze medals. This story will remain alive a bit longer, and so will the misinformation and abuse that's become inextricable.", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, row marches into final", "body": "The Algerian boxer embroiled in a major gender controversy at the Paris Olympics won her semi-final on Tuesday to guarantee at least a silver medal in front of a raucous Roland Garros crowd that chanted her name.\n\nImane Khelif defeated Thailand's 2023 world silver medallist Janjaem Suwannapheng in a unanimous points decision to march into Friday's final in the women's 66kg category.\n\n\"I am like all athletes, I am here to achieve my dream,\" Khelif told AFP afterwards.\n\nREAD MORE:\n\nGender controversy in Paris: Cebu sports community weighs-in\n\nAs gender row engulfs Paris Olympics boxing, what is testosterone?\n\nParis Olympics: Gender row explodes after Algerian boxer's quick win\n\nTaiwan's Lin Yu-ting, the other boxer in the eye of a storm over her eligibility, is herself sure to take home at least bronze at a different weight.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif and Lin both fought at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago but there was no controversy at the time and neither won a medal.\n\nBoth were disqualified from last year's world championships after failing gender eligibility tests, but were cleared to compete in Paris.\n\nKhelif was given the biggest roar of the night as she entered the arena at Roland Garros, usually home to Grand Slam tennis but hosting Olympic boxing and a sizeable number of Algerian fans with flags.\n\nCries of \"Imane, Imane\" rang out repeatedly before and during the bout.\n\nREAD MORE: 'Facts don't care about feelings,' they say -- unless it's women who don't look 'feminine'\n\nThe Thai Janjaem, who had a clear height disadvantage, took a standing count in the third round after feeling the full power of the superior Algerian.\n\nAt the end of the fight at the 15,000-seated Court Philippe-Chatrier, which was close to capacity, the two fighters greeted each other warmly and shook hands.\n\nKhelif did a dance in the middle of the ring, to more roars of approval.\n\nShe faces Yang Liu for gold after the Chinese boxer beat Taiwan's Chen Nien-chin in the other semi-final on points.\n\n\"I am focusing on the competition and other things are not important. The important thing is that I am in the final now,\" Khelif told BeIN Sports.\n\n\"I am very proud of this new achievement. I gave everything I had. We worked as a team for years and the dream has become a reality.\n\n\"I hope to focus and be up to the responsibility in the dream final.\"\n\nThe beaten Thai moved to play down the furore.\n\n\"I had heard about the news regarding her, but I wasn't following it closely,\" she said. \"She is a woman, but she is very strong.\"\n\nChaotic\n\nThe gender controversy ignited when Khelif defeated Angela Carini in 46 seconds in her opening bout in the French capital, the Italian reduced to tears and abandoning the fight after suffering a badly hurt nose.\n\nThe 2023 world championships, from which Lin and Khelif were expelled, were run by the International Boxing Association (IBA) but the International Olympic Committee (IOC) is organising the sport at the Games because of financial, governance and ethical concerns at the IBA.\n\nThe IBA's Kremlin-linked president Umar Kremlev claimed at a chaotic press conference on Monday that both fighters had \"genetic testing that shows that these are men\".\n\nThe IOC has leapt to the defense of Khelif and Lin, with president Thomas Bach saying they were born and raised as women, and have passports saying that.\n\nThe 28-year-old Lin semi-final success", "body": "Hundreds of flag-waving Algerian supporters turned the normally genteel surroundings of Phillippe-Chatrier Court at Roland Garros into a cauldron of noise as boxer Imane Khelif sealed her place in the Olympic women's welterweight final.\n\nChants of \"Imane\" tumbled down from the stands as Khelif, who is one of two boxers at the centre of a gender eligibility row, dominated her opponent Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand to confirm she will get the chance to emulate compatriot Hocine Soltani, who won lightweight gold in 1996.\n\nThe participation of Khelif and Chinese Taipei featherweight Lin Yu-ting has caused an international storm since Khelif beat Angela Carini of Italy in just 46 seconds in her opening bout last Thursday.\n\nBoth Khelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association (IBA) during last year's World Championships for failing to meet gender eligibility criteria.\n\nHowever, the IBA, which was was expelled by the International Olympic Commitee (IOC) over financial and corruption concerns, has failed to provide any proof of its findings.\n\nOn Monday, an IBA press conference descended into farce as controversial president Umar Kremlev made baseless claims about Lin and Khelif and launched an astonishing tirade against IOC president Thomas Bach.\n\nKhelif and Lin were allowed to return to competition by the IOC, which is effectively administering the Paris 2024 boxing tournament in the IBA's absence.\n\nThe case has aroused global interest, with figures such as former United States {"uri": "8262477098", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:21:18", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:21:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:20:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/08/06/embattled-algerian-olympic-boxer-imane-khelif-advances-to-gold-medal-bout/", "title": "Embattled Algerian Olympic boxer Imane Khelif advances to gold-medal bout", "body": "Algeria's Imane Khelif celebrates after defeating Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng in their women's 66 kg semifinal boxing match at the 2024 Summer Olympics on Tuesday in Paris, France. John Locher/Associated Press\n\nPARIS -- Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria has advanced to the gold-medal bout in the women's welterweight division with a semifinal victory at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night amid scrutiny over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared and chanted her name throughout her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday.\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nShe controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing eight-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches. Khelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris.\n\nAfter hugging Suwannapheng, Khelif celebrated in the ring, running wildly in place while pumping her fists as the crowd roared for her. With one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal, joining Hocine Soltani (1996).\n\nThe ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the center of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender.\n\nIn an interview with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nKhelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal - and now she's one win away from claiming it.\n\nKhelif entered the ring against Suwannapheng to cheers echoing through the famed tennis arena. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose stigmatization by the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association has been taken very personally in her country.\n\nBoth fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.\n\nThe fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing eight-count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary - as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nRelated Stories Latest Articles", into final", "body": "Imane Khelif defeated Thailand's 2023 world silver medallist Janjaem Suwannapheng in a unanimous points decision.\n\nTHE ALGERIAN boxer embroiled in a major gender controversy at the Paris Olympics won her semi-final on Tuesday to guarantee at least a silver medal in front of a raucous Roland Garros crowd that chanted her name.\n\nImane Khelif defeated Thailand's 2023 world silver medallist Janjaem Suwannapheng in a unanimous points decision to march into Friday's final in the women's 66kg category.\n\nTaiwan's Lin Yu-ting, the other boxer in the eye of a storm over her eligibility, is herself sure to take home at least bronze at a different weight.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif and Lin both fought at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago but there was no controversy at the time and neither won a medal.\n\nBoth were disqualified from last year's world championships after failing gender eligibility tests, but were cleared to compete in Paris.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nKhelif was given the biggest roar of the night as she entered the arena at Roland Garros, usually home to Grand Slam tennis but hosting Olympic boxing and a sizeable number of Algerian fans with flags.\n\nCries of \"Imane, Imane\" rang out repeatedly before and during the bout.\n\nThe Thai Janjaem, who had a clear height disadvantage, took a standing count in the third round after feeling the full power of the superior Algerian.\n\nAt the end of the fight at the 15,000-seated Court Philippe-Chatrier, which was close to capacity, the two fighters greeted each other warmly and shook hands.\n\nKhelif did a dance in the middle of the ring, to more roars of approval.\n\nShe faces Yang Liu for gold after the Chinese boxer beat Taiwan's Chen Nien-chin in the other semi-final on points.\n\nThe gender controversy ignited when Khelif defeated Angela Carini in 46 seconds in her opening bout in the French capital, the Italian reduced to tears and abandoning the fight after suffering a badly hurt nose.\n\nThe 2023 world championships, from which Lin and Khelif were expelled, were run by the International Boxing Association (IBA) but the International Olympic Committee (IOC) is organising the sport at the Games because of financial, governance and ethical concerns at the IBA.\n\nThe IBA's Kremlin-linked president Umar Kremlev claimed at a chaotic press conference on Monday that both fighters had \"genetic testing that shows that these are men\".\n\nThe IOC has leapt to the defence of Khelif and Lin, with president Thomas Bach saying they were born and raised as women, and have passports saying that.\n\nThe 28-year-old Lin fights in the semi-finals of the women's 57kg division on Wednesday.\n\n- \u00a9 AFP 2024", "source": {"uri": "the42.ie", "dataType": {"uri": "8262538449", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:33:59", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:33:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T22:27:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/olympics-boxing-algerian-khelif-wins-womens-semi-final-amid-gender-dispute/2211686/", "title": "Olympics-Boxing-Algerian Khelif wins women's semi-final amid gender dispute", "body": "\"I don't want anything to be said about the controversy,\" Khelif said after her win.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association from the 2023 World Championships in New Delhi, with the body saying in a shambolic press conference on Monday that a sex chromosome test had ruled both of them ineligible.\n\nAt those World Championships, Khelif beat Suwannapheng by unanimous decision in the semi-finals before being disqualified. Suwannapheng competed in the final after Khelif's disqualification and won silver.\n\nKhelif and Lin are competing in the Olympics after the International Olympic Committee stripped the IBA of its status as the sport's governing body in 2023 and took control of organising the boxing in Paris.\n\nThe IOC has rejected the results of the IBA-ordered tests as arbitrary and illegitimate, saying there was no reason to conduct them.\n\nAt these Games, the IOC is using boxing eligibility rules that were applied at the 2016 and 2021 Olympics which do not include gender testing.\n\nAlgerian fans flocked into a repurposed Court Philippe Chatrier, devoid of its iconic red clay, looking to support Khelif and screamed \"Imane, Imane, Imane\" ahead of the bout, while also booing Suwannapheng on entry.\n\nIn a cautious first round, both boxers attempted to keep their distance and engaged sparingly, but Khelif used her jab to better effect than her Thai opponent.\n\nSuwannapheng connected with a big right hand in the second, but the rangy Algerian's excellent technique allowed her to keep landing shots and sweep the judge's scorecards.\n\nKhelif threw caution to the wind and went after Suwannapheng in the final round, peppering her with jarring shots to claim the win by unanimous decision.\n\nBoth boxers touched gloves in a sign of respect after the fight, and when Khelif was announced as winner a deafening roar erupted from the fans in attendance.\n\n\"I just had the performance I was looking to deliver today to make the fans happy,\" Khelif said.\n\nKhelif waited until her opponent left the ring before celebrating, jogging on the spot with an enormous grin on her face before leaving and shadow-boxing her way to the doctor's station for a quick medical check.\n\n\"I have not followed the controversy closely but all I know is that she is a woman and she is a strong fighter,\" Suwannapheng said.\n\nKhelif will face Yang Liu of China in the final on Friday.\n\nLin also reached the semi-finals in the featherweight category, where she will take on Turkey's Esra Yildiz on Wednesday.\n\nThe storm surrounding Khelif and Lin erupted when the Algerian's opponent Angela Carini pulled out of their round-of-16 bout last week after just 46 seconds, saying she felt intense pain and feared for her safety after being hit with a barrage of punches.\n\nIn the aftermath of Carini's withdrawal, the gender furore swept social media, with people such as Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling and Tesla founder Elon Musk voicing their opposition to the two boxers competing at the Games.\n\nFollowing the bout, Italian Carini apologised to Khelif and said she did not harbour any ill feeling toward the Algerian.\n\n(Reporting by Julien Pretot, Philip O'Connor, Ashraf Hamed Atta, Layli Foroudi and Aadi Nair in Paris; Editing by Toby Davis and Bill Berkrot)", "source": {"uri": Khelif and Suwannapheng embraced in the middle of the ring after the third round.\n\nThe referee raised Khelif's arm as the winner.\n\nKhelif breezed through the first two fights of the Olympics, defeating Hungarian Luca Anna Hamori via unanimous decision and picking up a victory over Italian Angela Carini.\n\nThe boxer had been under the microscope over a gender eligibility controversy that started with a disqualification at the 2023 International Boxing Association World Championships.\n\nKhelif and the International Olympic Committee have maintained that the Algerian Olympian is eligible to compete. I know I'm a talented person and this is a gift to all Algerians.\"\n\nKhelif has been in the spotlight since her opening bout due to an eligibility row that has dominated headlines and sparked online abuse.\n\nKhelif and Taiwanese boxer Lin Yu-ting are both allowed to take part in the Olympics, with the International Olympic Committee (IOC) adopting different criteria to the International Boxing Association (IBA) who disqualified both from last year's World Championships due to the results of an unspecified eligibility test.\n\nKhelif will face China's Yang Liu in the women's welterweight {"uri": "8262584093", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "23:25:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T23:25:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T23:24:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.nbcnewyork.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/boxer-imane-khelif-fight-olympic-gold-gender-misconceptions/5678138/", "title": "Boxer Imane Khelif will fight for Olympic gold amid outcry over gender misconceptions", "body": "Algerian boxer Imane Khelif will fight for an Olympic gold medal Friday night amid the intense scrutiny over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nIn her semifinal on Tuesday, Khelif was victorious over Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand at the Paris Olympics at Roland Garros, Paris' famed tennis complex. She will now face China's Liu Yang in the women's 66-kilogram finals on Friday night for the gold medal.\n\nKhelif, a two-time Olympian, has already clinched her first Olympic medal, which is also Algeria's first medal in women's boxing (Olympic boxing does not stage bronze-medal bouts, so the losers of both semifinal bouts receive bronze). She needs one more victory to claim only Algeria's second boxing gold medal, following Hocine Soltani in 1996.\n\nKhelif comfortably won her first two fights in Paris, but the ending of her first bout propelled her into a worldwide divide over gender identity and regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender.\n\nIn an interview with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nThe IOC and its president, Thomas Bach, have repeatedly defended the Olympic eligibility of Khelif and fellow boxer Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association in the middle of last year's world championships over what it claimed were failed eligibility tests for the women's competition. The IBA has been banished from the Olympics since before the Tokyo Games, and the body struggled to articulate the reasoning for its decisions on Khelif and Lin at a news conference Monday.\n\nLin also has clinched a medal and advanced to the Olympic semifinals. She fights Esra Yildiz Kahraman of Turkey in the first bout Wednesday night at Roland Garros.", "source": {"uri": "nbcnewyork.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC New York"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8262505739", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:54:06", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:54:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:53:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.bangkokpost.com/sports/2843037/algerian-khelif-wins-womens-semi-final-amid-gender-dispute", "title": "Algerian Khelif wins women\"s semi-final amid gender dispute", "body": "Khelif, a silver medallist at the 2022 worlds, and Taiwanese boxer Lin Yu-ting have been in the spotlight at the Olympics as part of a storm that has dominated headlines and been the subject of much discussion on social media platforms.\n\nKhelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association from the 2023 World Championships in New Delhi, with the body saying in a shambolic press conference on Monday that a sex chromosome test had ruled both of them ineligible.\n\nAt those World Championships, Khelif beat Suwannapheng by unanimous decision in the semi-finals before being disqualified. Suwannapheng competed in the final after Khelif's disqualification and won silver.\n\nKhelif and Lin are competing in the Olympics after the International Olympic Committee stripped the IBA of its status as the sport's governing body in 2023 and took control of organising the boxing in Paris.\n\nThe IOC has rejected the results of the IBA-ordered tests as arbitrary and illegitimate, saying there was no reason to conduct them.\n\nAt these Games, the IOC is using boxing eligibility rules that were applied at the 2016 and 2021 Olympics which do not include gender testing.\n\nFAN SUPPORT\n\nAlgerian fans flocked into a repurposed Court Philippe Chatrier, devoid of its iconic red clay, looking to support Khelif and screamed \"Imane, Imane, Imane\" ahead of the bout, while also booing Suwannapheng on entry.\n\nIn a cautious first round, both boxers attempted to keep their distance and engaged sparingly, but Khelif used her jab to better effect than her Thai opponent.\n\nSuwannapheng connected with a big right hand in the second, but the rangy Algerian's excellent technique allowed her to keep landing shots and sweep the judge's scorecards.\n\nKhelif threw caution to the wind and went after Suwannapheng in the final round, peppering her with jarring shots to claim the win by unanimous decision.\n\nBoth boxers touched gloves in a sign of respect after the fight, and when Khelif was announced as winner a deafening roar erupted from the fans in attendance.\n\nKhelif waited until her opponent left the ring before celebrating, jogging on the spot with an enormous grin on her face before leaving and shadow-boxing her way to the doctor's station for a quick medical check.\n\nKhelif will face Yang Liu of China in the final on Friday.\n\nLin also reached the semi-finals in the featherweight category, where she will take on Turkey's Esra Yildiz on Wednesday.\n\nThe storm surrounding Khelif and Lin erupted when the Algerian's opponent Angela Carini pulled out of their round-of-16 bout last week after just 46 seconds, saying she felt intense pain and feared for her safety after being hit with a barrage of punches.\n\nIn the aftermath of Carini's withdrawal, the gender furore swept social media, with people such as Harry Potter author J.K. Rowling and Tesla founder Elon Musk voicing their opposition to the two boxers competing at the Games.\n\nFollowing the bout, Italian Carini apologised to Khelif and said she did not harbour any ill {"uri": "2024-08-446188988", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:29:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:29:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:12:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/boxer-imane-khelif-advances-to-gold-medal-bout-with-another-victory-amid-gender-misconceptions/article_3bf2574c-97a4-5452-b217-3579c2976381.html", "title": "Boxer Imane Khelif advances to gold-medal bout with another victory amid gender misconceptions", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria has advanced to the gold-medal bout in the women's welterweight division with a semifinal victory at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night amid scrutiny over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared and chanted her name throughout her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday.\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nShe controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing 8-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches. Khelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris.\n\nAfter hugging Suwannapheng, Khelif celebrated in the ring, running wildly in place while pumping her fists as the crowd roared for her.\n\nWith one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal, joining Hocine Soltani (1996).\n\nThe ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the center of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.\n\nCarini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender.\n\nIn an interview with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.\n\nKhelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal -- and now she's one win away from claiming it.\n\nKhelif entered the ring against Suwannapheng to cheers echoing through the famed tennis arena. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose stigmatization by the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association has been taken very personally in her country.\n\nBoth fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.\n\nThe fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing 8-count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary -- as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\nAP Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "title": "Paris 2024 Olympics: Algerian boxer in Olympic gender row, Imane Khelif, marches into final", "body": "The Algerian boxer embroiled in a major gender controversy at the Paris Olympics won her semi-final on Tuesday to guarantee at least a silver medal in front of a raucous Roland Garros crowd that chanted her name.\n\nImane Khelif defeated Thailand's 2023 world silver medallist Janjaem Suwannapheng in a unanimous points decision to march into Friday's final in the women's 66kg category.\n\nTaiwan's Lin Yu-ting, the other boxer in the eye of a storm over her eligibility, is herself sure to take home at least bronze at a different weight.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif and Lin both fought at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago but there was no controversy at the time and neither won a medal.\n\nBoth were disqualified from last year's world championships after failing gender eligibility tests, but were cleared to compete in Paris.\n\nKhelif was given the biggest roar of the night as she entered the arena at Roland Garros, usually home to Grand Slam tennis but hosting Olympic boxing and a sizeable number of Algerian fans with flags.\n\nCries of \"Imane, Imane\" rang out repeatedly before and during the bout.\n\nThe Thai, who had a clear height disadvantage, took a standing count in the third round after feeling the full power of the superior Algerian.\n\nAt the end of the fight at the 15,000-seated Court Philippe-Chatrier, which was close to capacity, the two fighters greeted each other warmly and shook hands.\n\nKhelif did a dance in the middle of the ring, to more roars of approval.\n\nKhelif faces China's Yang Liu or Taiwan's Chen Nien-chin for gold.\n\nThe gender controversy ignited when Khelif defeated Angela Carini in 46 seconds in her opening bout in the French capital, the Italian reduced to tears and abandoning the fight after suffering a badly hurt nose.\n\nThe 2023 world championships, from which Lin and Khelif were expelled, were run by the International Boxing Association (IBA) but the International Olympic Committee (IOC) is organising the sport at the Games because of financial, governance and ethical concerns at the IBA.\n\nThe IBA's Kremlin-linked president Umar Kremlev claimed at a chaotic press conference on Monday that both fighters had \"genetic testing that shows that these are men\".\n\nThe IOC has leapt to the defence of Khelif and Lin, with president Thomas Bach saying they were born and raised as women, and have passports saying that.\n\nThe 28-year-old Lin fights in the semi-finals of the women's 57kg division on Wednesday.\n\nLatest on SportstarParis 2024 Olympics: Algerian boxer in Olympic gender row, Imane Khelif, marches into final AFPParis 2024 Olympics: Brazil stuns Spain to reach women's football final {"uri": "8262573949", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "23:12:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T23:12:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T23:11:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.bpr.org/npr-news/2024-08-06/algerias-imane-khelif-ensnared-in-political-controversy-will-box-for-olympic-gold", "title": "Algeria's Imane Khelif, ensnared in political controversy, will box for Olympic gold", "body": "NPR is in Paris for the 2024 Summer Olympics. For more of our coverage from the games head to our latest updates.\n\nPARIS -- Imane Khelif, the Algerian boxer at the center of political controversy over participation in women's sports, will compete for the Olympic gold medal in women's boxing.\n\nAway from Paris, criticism has erupted over the past week around Khelif's participation in the Olympics amid claims that she failed two gender eligibility tests administered by a boxing federation -- tests that Olympic officials have dismissed as \"illegitimate\" as they have defended her participation.\n\nBut in the stands of Roland-Garros Stadium, dozens of Algerian flags hung over the seats, as hundreds of men and women dressed in green and red cheered raucously for Khelif.\n\nOver three rounds in the ring Tuesday, Khelif traded blows with her opponent, Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng, in the 66kg weight class semifinal. With her win (a unanimous decision by the five judges), Khelif is set to compete Friday in the gold medal match, in which she will face China's Yang Liu.\n\n\"I don't care about criticism. I care about competition. God willing, I will perform well in the final,\" Khelif told reporters after Tuesday's bout. \"I will do everything I can to make it enjoyable to watch around the world.\"\n\nAfter the official raised her hand to declare her victory, Khelif danced joyfully in the ring as Algerian fans roared their approval.\n\nThe political controversy around Khelif that erupted over the past week centers on a decision last year by the International Boxing Association to disqualify her and another female boxer from some competitions by claiming that they had failed two unspecified gender eligibility tests. The second boxer, Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan, is also competing in the Olympics.\n\nKhelif, 25, is a woman and has competed for years in women's boxing, in which she has accumulated a typical record of wins and losses against her female competition.\n\n\"They were born as girls, registered as female passports, have fought at the senior level for six years with no issues,\" International Olympic Committee spokesperson Mark Adams said on Sunday.\n\nBut the Russia-linked boxing federation has refused to release any details about those tests, and the disqualification was announced shortly after Khelif defeated a Russian boxer.\n\nIn a chaotic press conference Monday, IBA officials raised more questions than they answered about the tests. IBA president Umar Kremlev, speaking by videoconference from Russia, said through a translator that their tests had shown elevated levels of testosterone -- but that claim directly contradicted a previous statement from the IBA that said the boxers had not undergone a testosterone exam.\n\nThe IOC says the IBA shared the results of the tests, which Olympic officials have denounced as they continue to defend the boxers' participation.\n\n\"The method of the testing, the idea of the testing -- which kind of happened overnight -- none of it was legitimate,\" Adams said. The IOC broke ties with the IBA last year over long-standing concerns about corruption.\n\nStill, the controversy has led to a swell of harassment online targeted at Khelif and Lin, who will compete in her own semifinal in a different weight class on Wednesday. Earlier in the tournament, Algerian Olympic officials filed a complaint with the IOC to protest harmful posts made online by one of Khelif's competitors; the IOC ordered the competitor to remove them.\n\n\"It can destroy people, it can kill people's thoughts, spirit and mind. It can divide people. And because of that, I ask them to refrain from bullying,\" Khelif said Sunday in an interview with SNTV, a sports news service.\n\nAt the stadium, fans of Algeria said they rejected the claims against Khelif and decried the online harassment that has surrounded her. \"I think she is really brave to get into the ring today despite the relentless campaign against her,\" said Abdelslam Afs. \"We are all here to support her.\"\n\nAnother fan, the Algiers-born Yacine Bouzydy, said he originally hadn't planned to attend Tuesday's bout, as he doesn't closely follow sports. But when he heard about the controversy surrounding Khelif, he decided to attend to show his support and \"give her energy,\" he said.\n\n\"Algeria is quite a conservative country to France and to other European countries. But for this specific story, the role has changed somehow,\" he said.\n\n\"I can imagine that it was very, very hard for her to go beyond this and to compete and to win the bronze medal, at least,\" Bouzydy said. \"I hope it will end with a gold medal. And even if not, Algerian people are very happy.\"", "source": {"uri": "bpr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "bpr.org"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": It can divide people.\n\n\"And because of that, I ask them to refrain from bullying.\"\n\nThe victories of Khelif and fellow boxer Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan in the ring in Paris have become some of the biggest stories of the Paris Games.\n\nBoth women have clinched their first Olympic medals even as they have faced online abuse based on unsubstantiated claims about their gender, drawing them into a wider divide over changing attitudes toward gender identity and regulations in sports.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif acknowledged her ordeal while competing in the most important event of her athletic career.\n\n\"My family ... are worried about me. from the Olympics, that both Khelif and Lin failed unspecified eligibility tests for the women's competition at last year's world championships.\n\nKhelif declined to answer when asked whether she had
