{"uri": "8262493655", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:40:20", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:40:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:38:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/imane-khelif-cruises-women-boxing-213126772.html", "title": "Imane Khelif cruises into women's boxing final with dominant victory over Thai opponent", "body": "Imane Khelif, the Algerian at the centre of the Olympics gender outcry, will box for gold after easing through her semi-final in more emotionally-charged scenes in Paris.\n\nThe toxic issue tearing apart the sport at these Games now moves on to Friday's final after Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng was easily overhauled.\n\n\"Khelif, Khelif, Khelif,\" the chants rang out as raucous French-Algerian supporters once again showed up to rally behind beleaguered Khelif.\n\nHowever, for what felt like the biggest event in town, the BBC instead opted to lead with highlights of other events amid calls from both Khelif and Games chiefs to show \"restraint\".\n\nThe 25-year-old was on the front foot from the start, comprehensively winning rounds one and two, leaving the significantly shorter Thai facing an impossible task in the third.\n\nIn a rarity for women's boxing, the battered Suwannapheng was given a standing count in the third round such was the ferocity of Khelif's punching.\n\nHaving breezed through her previous three rounds despite red hot scrutiny, this should have been a tougher showdown for Khelif, ranked only three places above her Thai opponent.\n\nThere were also no protests in the ring from Suwannapheng, who had said ahead of the 66-kg semi-final that she did not care which gender Khelif was.\n\n\"I'm not sure if she's got stronger or if her male hormones have increased,\" she said. \"I'm not afraid because we're evenly matched.\"\n\nAfter the fight finished, there was no animosity as Khelif pumped her knees up and down and danced a jig. At least 50 flags in support of Khelif were draped around the 15,000-capacity arena, which saved its biggest roar for the contentious showdown.\n\nFor fair sport campaigners, this has been a saga with only losers as Khelif now closes in on gold despite allegedly failing two sex tests in 2022 and 2023.\n\nNot much more to add on the fight really. Suwannapheng fought bravely but in truth she was several levels below her opponent this evening. It's just a flip of the coin sometimes and in this case it didn't go my way.\n\n\"It's been an amazing experience, I'm so grateful for everyone who has helped me along the way.\n\n\"It's been an amazing journey, I have been boxing for 12, 13 years and the amount of people and support I have had throughout those years has been so influential in me achieving what I have achieved tonight, creating history for myself, my family and my city.\n\n\"Even talking now brings pride but I'm a winner and it obviously is disappointing not to be able to box for the gold on Friday.\n\n\"I don't know [how hometown - Colchester - will react], we will soon find out next week! Verde hits back though as another right hand lands. Nice clash of styles...a traditional Mexican brawler against a more fluid counter-puncher.\n\nIt's been a disappointing Olympics for GB boxing but the man from Colchester has the chance to make it one to remember. A spot to fight for the gold medal is on the line.\n\nAs you might have already read, tonight's fights are being held on Court Phillipe Chatrier at Roland-Garros rather than the North Paris Arena. That was always the plan for the semi-finals and finals of the respective weight categories.\n\n...has come to an end. For my money that's a win for Asadkhuja Muydinkhujaev. Omari Jones is a real talent but he looked a little ragged through those three rounds.\n\nAND IT IS THE UZBEK BY SPLIT DECISION. He will face either Lewis Richardson or Marco Verde for the gold medal.\n\nThat fight follows next.\n\nAs already mentioned, the IBA press conference about Imane Khelif, held yesterday in Paris, was a sight and a sound for sore eyes. Heavily delayed, technically deficient and featuring at least one individual who arguably did more to undermine the credibility of the organisation than the very fact that the IOC has cut ties with it.\n\nCatch up with everything that happened HERE.\n\n...here at Roland-Garros this evening. Lewis Richardson faces Mexico's Marco Verde in the second semi-final in the men's welterweight.\n\nThe first semi-final, between Omari Jones of the USA and Uzbekistan's Asadkhuja Muydinkhujaev, is already underway.\n\nThe firestorm engulfing Imane Khelif at this Olympic Games has been relentless, exhausting, confusing and everything in between. So it gives me great pleasure to advise you all to saddle up because it's about to kick into gear again.\n\nThe Algerian faces Janjaem Suwannapheng in the semi-final of the women's welterweight this evening as he closes in on what would be a second gold medal for her nation at these games.\n\nSome will say that is all this evening is about. Others vehemently disagree. Like it or not, it's impossible to ignore the spectre of the failed gender eligibility test that has overshadowed her campaign.\n\nEven after the organisation that administered that test, the IBA, undermined its credibility with a shambolic and rhetoric-fuelled press conference on Monday, controversy still swirls.\n\nAmid all of this, there are Olympic medals on the line and so it would feel remiss to not spend any time whatsoever on the fight itself.\n\nKhelif and Suwannapheng met in the same stage of the 2023 world championships, with the Algerian coming out on top before her disqualification for failing the aforementioned gender test.\n\nThe winner will face either Taiwan's Chen Nien-chin or China's Yang Liu in Friday's final, with both losers being awarded bronze medals, as is the way in the single-elimination tournament that is Olympic boxing.\n\nA Khelif victory, of any kind, will surely ramp up the rhetoric yet further and she is a heavy favourite - as short as It's not clear under what criteria made for a failed test, -- which came after Khelif beat a Russian opponent -- was administered.\n\nIn an interview with SNTV on Sunday, Khelif spoke in Arabic about the backlash she's faced, while declining to answer whether she had undergone tests aside from doping tests.\n\n\"I send a message to all the people of the world to uphold the Olympic principles and the Olympic Charter, to refrain from bullying all athletes, because this has effects, massive effects,\" Khelif said, as translated by the Associated Press. \"It can destroy people, it can kill people's thoughts, spirit and mind. It can divide people. And because of that, I ask them to refrain from bullying.\"\n\nKhelif burst into tears upon clinching at least a bronze medal with her win over Hungary's Anna Luca Hamori, telling reporters that she is female.\n\nSince Olympic boxing does not have third-place bouts, both Khelif and Taiwan's Lin Yu-ting -- another female boxer who failed the IBA's gender test -- were guaranteed medals before {"uri": "8262492332", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:37:11", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:37:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:36:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/08/06/g-s1-15720/imane-khelif-algerian-boxer-gender-olympic-gold", "title": "Imane Khelif, the Algerian snared in political controversy, will box for Olympic gold", "body": "Imane Khelif of Algeria (blue) punches Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand during the Women's 66kg semifinal bout on Tuesday at the Paris Olympic Games. Matthew Stockman/Getty Images hide caption\n\nNPR is in Paris for the 2024 Summer Olympics. For more of our coverage from the games head to our latest updates.\n\nPARIS -- Imane Khelif, the Algerian boxer at the center of political controversy over participation in women's sports, will compete for the Olympic gold medal in women's boxing.\n\nOutside of Paris, criticism has erupted over the past week around Khelif's participation in the Olympics amid claims that she failed two gender eligibility tests administered by a boxing federation -- tests that Olympic officials have dismissed as \"illegitimate\" as they have defended her participation.\n\nBut in the stands of Roland-Garros Stadium, dozens of Algerian flags hung over the seats, as hundreds of men and women dressed in green and red cheered raucously for Khelif.\n\nOver three rounds in the ring Tuesday, Khelif traded blows with her opponent, Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng, in the 66kg weight class semifinal.\n\nWith her win, she is set to compete Friday in the gold medal match.\n\nAfter the official raised her hand to mark her victory, Khelif danced joyfully in the ring as Algerian fans roared their approval.\n\nThe political controversy around Khelif that erupted over the past week centers on a decision last year by the International Boxing Association to disqualify her and another female boxer from some competitions by claiming that they had failed two unspecified gender eligibility tests. The second boxer, Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan, is also competing in the Olympics.\n\nKhelif, 25, is a woman and has competed for years in women's boxing, in which she has accumulated a typical record of wins and losses against her female competition.\n\n\"They were born as girls, registered as female passports, have fought at the senior level for six years with no issues,\" International Olympic Committee spokesperson Mark Adams said on Sunday.\n\nBut the Russia-linked boxing federation has refused to release any details about those tests, and the disqualification was announced shortly after Khelif defeated a Russian boxer.\n\nIn a chaotic press conference Monday, IBA officials raised more questions than they answered about the tests. IBA president Umar Kremlev, speaking by videoconference from Russia, said through a translator that their tests had shown elevated levels of testosterone -- but that claim directly contradicted a previous statement from the IBA that said the boxers had not undergone a testosterone exam.\n\nThe IOC says the IBA shared the results of the test Olympic officials have denounced and continue to defend the boxers' participation.\n\n\"The method of the testing, the idea of the testing -- which kind of happened overnight -- none of it was legitimate,\" Adams said. The IOC broke ties with the IBA last year over long-standing concerns about corruption.\n\nStill, the controversy has led to a swell of harassment online targeted at Khelif and Lin, who will compete in her own semifinal in a different weight class on Wednesday.\n\n\"It can destroy people, it can kill people's thoughts, spirit and mind. It can divide people. And because of that, I ask them to refrain from bullying,\" Khelif said Sunday in an interview with SNTV, a sports news service.\n\nAt the stadium, fans of Algeria said they rejected the claims against Khelif and decried the online harassment that has surrounded her. \"I think she is really brave to get into the ring today despite the relentless campaign against her,\" said Abdelslam Afs. \"We are all here to support her.\"\n\nAnother fan, the Algiers-born Yacine Bouzydy, said he originally hadn't planned to attend Tuesday's bout, as he doesn't closely follow sports. But when he heard about the controversy surrounding Khelif, he decided to attend to show his support and \"give her energy,\" he said.\n\n\"Algeria is quite a conservative country to France and to other European countries. But for this specific story, the role has changed somehow,\" he said.\n\n\"I can imagine that it was very, very hard for her to go beyond this and to compete and to win the bronze medal, at least,\" Bouzydy said. \"I hope it will end with a gold medal. And even if not, Algerian people are very happy.\"", "source": {"uri": "npr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "NPR"}, "authors": [{"uri": "becky_sullivan@npr.org", "name": "Becky Sullivan", "type": {"uri": "8262541614", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:32:49", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:32:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T22:32:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://theglobalherald.com/news/algerian-boxer-imane-khelif-advances-to-olympic-final-amid-controversy/", "title": "Algerian Boxer Imane Khelif Advances to Olympic Final Amid Controversy - The Global Herald", "body": "Imane Khelif, the Algerian boxer, has secured her place in the Olympic final for the women's 66kg category after a decisive win against Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng in Paris. This victory comes against the backdrop of a dispute regarding Khelif's eligibility, which has drawn significant attention.\n\nKhelif, along with another boxer, faced disqualification from last year's World Championships by the International Boxing Association (IBA) due to alleged failures in gender eligibility tests. Notably, despite this controversy, Khelif has been allowed to compete at the Olympics.\n\nDuring her semi-final match, held at the Court Philippe Chatrier, a venue typically used for tennis, Khelif showcased her strength and skill, dominating Suwannapheng to win by unanimous decision. The support from the crowd was palpable, contributing to an electrifying atmosphere.\n\nThis win marks a significant milestone for Khelif, as she progresses to her first Olympic final, having previously been eliminated in the quarter-finals at the Tokyo Games three years prior.\n\nIn the gold medal match, Khelif will face Liu Yang of China. Should she win, it would make her the first athlete from Algeria to claim an Olympic gold in boxing.\n\nReflecting on her journey, Khelif stated, \"I am focused. I am here for a good performance and my dream. I will give everything I have for the final.\"\n\nThe semi-final bout concluded with Khelif celebrating joyously on the canvas, indicating her elation at the victory. Suwannapheng, acknowledging Khelif's strength, commented on the challenge she posed during the match, saying, \"She is a woman, but she is very strong. I tried to use my speed, but my opponent was just too strong.\"\n\nKhelif expressed gratitude towards the cheering fans and her supporters back in Algeria, reflecting, \"I am very happy. I want to thank all of the people of Algeria who came here.\" Her participation in the Olympics continues to ignite discussions regarding the policies governing athlete eligibility and recognition.\n\nAs Khelif prepares for her impending final match, the sporting world watches closely, not only for her performance but also for the broader implications it may have on future {"uri": "8262540649", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:31:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:31:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T22:30:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.nbcchicago.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/algerian-boxer-imane-khelif-advances-to-gold-medal-fight-with-another-victory/3514675/", "title": "Algerian boxer Imane Khelif advances to gold-medal bout with another victory", "body": "Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria advanced to the gold-medal bout in the women's welterweight division at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night, moving one win away from what she calls the best response to the worldwide scrutiny she has faced over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nWith one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal and its first in women's boxing.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared for her and chanted her name repeatedly during her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday against Yang Liu of China.\n\nKhelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier. She then controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing 8-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches.\n\nKhelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris. She has made the most important tournament run of her international career amid criticism and stigmatization stemming from the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association's decision to disqualify her from the world championships last year for allegedly failing an eligibility test.\n\nThe Algerian athlete spoke about her tumultuous Olympic experience on Sunday night in an interview with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press.\n\n\"I send a message to all the people of the world to uphold the Olympic principles and the Olympic Charter, to refrain from bullying all athletes, because this has effects, massive effects,\" Khelif said in Arabic. \"It can destroy people, it can kill people's thoughts, spirit and mind. It can divide people. And because of that, I ask them to refrain from bullying.\"\n\nThe victories of Khelif and fellow boxer Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan in the ring in Paris have become one of the biggest stories of the Paris Games. Both women have clinched their first Olympic medals even as they have faced online abuse based on unsubstantiated claims about their gender, drawing them into a wider divide over changing attitudes toward gender identity and regulations in sports.\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif acknowledged the pressure and pain of enduring this ordeal while competing far from home in the most important event of her athletic career.\n\n\"I am in contact with my family two days a week. I hope that they weren't affected deeply,\" she said. \"They are worried about me. God willing, this crisis will culminate in a gold medal, and that would be the best response.\"", "source": {"uri": "nbcchicago.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Chicago"}, "authors": [], Photograph: Richard Pelham/Reuters\n\nImane Khelif, the boxer at the centre of a gender dispute, beat Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng by unanimous decision in a Women's 66kg welterweight semi-final at the Paris Games on Tuesday to progress to the final at Roland Garros.\n\nKhelif, a silver medallist at the 2022 Worlds, and Taiwanese boxer Lin Yu-ting have been in the spotlight at the Olympics as part of a storm that has dominated headlines and been the subject of much discussion on social media platforms.\n\nIn a cautious first round, both boxers attempted to keep their distance and engaged sparingly, but Khelif used her jab to better effect than her Thai opponent.\n\nSuwannapheng connected with a big right hand in the second, but the rangy Algerian's excellent technique allowed her to keep landing shots and sweep the judge's scorecards.\n\nIMAGE: Imane Khelif and Janjaem Suwannapheng embrace after the bout. Photograph: Peter Cziborra/Reuters\n\nKhelif threw caution to the wind and went after Suwannapheng in the final round, peppering her with jarring shots to claim the win by unanimous decision.\n\nBoth boxers touched gloves in a sign of respect after the fight and when Khelif was announced as winner, a deafening roar erupted from the fans in attendance.\n\nKhelif waited until her opponent left the ring before celebrating, jogging on the spot with an enormous grin on her face before leaving and shadow-boxing her way to the doctor's station for a quick medical check.\n\nIn the final, Khelif will take on China's Yang Liu, who beat Taiwan's Chen Nien-chin 4-1 in the other semi-final.\n\nTHE OLYMPICS, 2024", "source": {"uri": "rediff.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rediff.com India Ltd."}, Suwannapheng, a fighter accustomed to closing the distance with her opponent by coming forward, endured several big hits as Khelif fired flurries of rights and lefts to prevent the Thai fighter from getting in close enough to do damage.\n\nIn the end, judges awarded all three rounds to Khelif.\n\nImane Khelif wins again!!!! She's on to the gold medal match!!! LET'S GO!!! pic.twitter.com/0oG9suO8qn\n\n-- Alejandra Caraballo (@Esqueer_) August 6, 2024\n\nKhelif and Taiwan's Lin Yu-ting have been at the center of controversy at the 2024 Paris Games because they both failed IBA gender tests at the last major women's international boxing event before the Olympics.\n\nIn 2023, the IBA President Umar Kremlev explained his organization's decision to disqualify Taiwan's Lin Yu-ting and Algeria's Imane Khelif from competing in the IBA's 2023 Women's World Boxing Championships, according to Russia's Tass News Agency. \"Based on DNA tests, we identified a number of athletes who tried to trick their colleagues into posing as women. According to the results of the tests, it was proved that they have XY chromosomes. Such athletes were excluded from competition,\" Kremlev said.\n\nKhelif was jubilant after the victory.\n\nKhelif's previous two victories included an opening bout against Italy's Angela Carini that lasted all of 46 seconds before the Italian quit the match, citing her Algerian opponent's \"power.\"\n\nAfter the fight, Carini told Italy's ASNA: \"I'm used to suffering. I've never taken a punch like that; it's impossible to continue. I'm nobody to say it's illegal.\n\n\"I got into the ring to fight. But I didn't feel like it anymore after the first minute. I started to feel a strong pain in my nose. I didn't give up, but a punch hurt too much and, so I said enough. I'm leaving with my head held high.\"\n\nKhelif's next victim was Hungary's Anna Luca Hamori. The fight went the distance, but the judges gave Khelif a 5-0 comprehensive victory.\n\nInternational outrage has erupted after each of Khelif's victories. However, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) backs the Alegerian and insists that all gender requirements to compete as a female have been met.\n\n\"Everyone competing in the women's category is complying with the competition eligibility rules,\" IOC spokesperson Mark Adams said. \"They are women in their passports, and it's stated that this is the case.\"", "source": {"uri": "breitbart.com", "title": "Algerian boxer delivers brutal blow to reach gold medal fight", "body": "Controversial Algerian boxer Imane Khelif is through to the gold medal bout at the Paris Olympics after winning her semi-final on Tuesday night (local time).\n\nKhelif, who has been as the centre of a global storm over questions about her gender, beat Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng in front of a parochial crowd at Roland Garros.\n\nThousands of Algerian fans turned out to support the 25-year-old.\n\nThey cheered \"Imane, Imane, Imane\" as she walked out to fight and released a deafening roar when she was declared the winner.\n\nThe result was almost certain after Khelif delivered her opponent a brutal blow in the third round that forced the referee to deliver a standing eight count.\n\nKhelif has been subject to a torrent of abuse since her round-of-16 bout against Italy's Angela Carini last week.\n\nThe match ended prematurely when Carini withdrew after 46 seconds, saying she feared for her life.\n\nThe incident sparked massive outrage and reignited a bitter feud between the International Olympic Committee and the International Boxing Association, which had disqualified Khelif and Taiwan's Li Lu-Ting from last year's world championship after they failed gender eligibility tests.\n\nThe IOC last year permanently stripped the IBA's Olympic accreditation over governance concerns that had dogged the organisation and its president Umar Kremlev, a close associate of Russian president Vladimir Putin.\n\nThe IOC took control of the boxing tournament at the Paris Games and deemed Khelif and Lu-Ting eligible to compete based on the fact they have passports stating they are female.\n\nIOC spokesman Mark Adams rejected the IBA's testing regime, describing it as ad hoc and arbitrary.\n\nOn Monday the IBA held a chaotic, two-hour press conference where Kremlev declared Khelif and Lu-Ting were men who should not be allowed to compete at the Olympics.\n\nHe also accused the IOC of corruption and said the IBA was standing up for the rights of women.\n\nIt said its testing showed Khelif and Lu-Ting had elevated levels of testosterone and had XY chromosomes, which is found in men.\n\nThe IBA said it could not release the result of its gender tests after receiving letters of demand from the Algerian and Taiwanese Olympic committees.\n\nBut IBA officials left behind notes at the event which said Khelif had an unfair advantage, and that XY athletes could punch 162 per cent harder than men.\n\nKhelif's appearance in the gold medal bout will ensure the controversy that has dominated headline at these Olympics will continue.\n\nShe will take on China's Liu Yang in the gold medal bout on Saturday morning (AEST).", "source": {"uri": "skynews.com.au", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-08-446188325", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:28:40", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:28:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:27:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.wesh.com/article/algerian-boxer-imane-khelif-advances-to-gold-medal-round/61807452", "title": "Algerian boxer Imane Khelif advances to gold-medal bout amid scrutiny over gender misconceptions", "body": "Boxer Imane Khelif of Algeria has advanced to the gold-medal bout in the women's welterweight division with a semifinal victory at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night amid scrutiny over misconceptions about her gender.Khelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared and chanted her name throughout her three-round fight. Khelif has won three consecutive bouts in Paris, and she will win either a gold or a silver medal when she completes the tournament on Friday.Khelif had already clinched Algeria's first medal in women's boxing before she stepped into the ring to rousing roars at Court Philippe Chatrier.She controlled her bout with Suwannapheng, who took a standing 8-count late in the third after absorbing a series of punches. Khelif has won every round on every judge's card in her two fights that have gone the distance in Paris.After hugging Suwannapheng, Khelif celebrated in the ring, running wildly in place while pumping her fists as the crowd roared for her.With one more victory, Khelif would win Algeria's second boxing gold medal, joining Hocine Soltani (1996).The ending of Khelif's first bout in Paris propelled her into the center of a worldwide divide over gender identity and safety regulations in sports. Her first opponent, Angela Carini of Italy, tearfully quit after just 46 seconds, saying she was in too much pain from Khelif's punches.Carini's abandonment of the fight led to comments from the likes of former U.S. President Donald Trump, \"Harry Potter\" writer J.K. Rowling and others falsely claiming Khelif was a man or transgender.In an interview with SNTV, a sports video partner of The Associated Press, Khelif said the wave of hateful scrutiny she is facing \"harms human dignity\" and called for an end to bullying athletes.Khelif also said she felt the \"best response\" to the uproar around her would be to win a gold medal -- and now she's one win away from claiming it.Khelif entered the ring against Suwannapheng to cheers echoing through the famed tennis arena. Roland Garros welcomed a prominent turnout from Algerian fans voicing their national pride in a boxer whose stigmatization by the Olympic-banished International Boxing Association has been taken very personally in her country.Both fighters came out aggressively, trading punches from distance. Khelif was more accurate while winning the first round on all five cards, and she repeated the performance in the second.The fight got more physical in the third, with Suwannapheng pushing forward to make a comeback. The bout was stopped for a standing 8-count late in the third when Suwannapheng absorbed a few head punches in succession, although Suwannapheng appeared to shrug as if it wasn't necessary -- as is often the case in Olympic boxing, where referees can stop a bout for relatively minor reasons.\n\nBoxer Imane Khelif of Algeria has advanced to the gold-medal bout in the women's welterweight division with a semifinal victory at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday night amid scrutiny over misconceptions about her gender.\n\nKhelif defeated Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand 5:0 in the semifinals at Roland Garros, where the crowd roared and chanted her name throughout her three-round fight. {"uri": "8262503887", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:51:14", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:51:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:50:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.gpb.org/news/2024/08/06/imane-khelif-the-algerian-snared-in-political-controversy-will-box-for-olympic-gold", "title": "Imane Khelif, the Algerian snared in political controversy, will box for Olympic gold", "body": "NPR is in Paris for the 2024 Summer Olympics. For more of our coverage from the games head to our latest updates.\n\nPARIS -- Imane Khelif, the Algerian boxer at the center of political controversy over participation in women's sports, will compete for the Olympic gold medal in women's boxing.\n\nOutside of Paris, criticism has erupted over the past week around Khelif's participation in the Olympics amid claims that she failed two gender eligibility tests administered by a boxing federation -- tests that Olympic officials have dismissed as \"illegitimate\" as they have defended her participation.\n\nBut in the stands of Roland-Garros Stadium, dozens of Algerian flags hung over the seats, as hundreds of men and women dressed in green and red cheered raucously for Khelif.\n\nOver three rounds in the ring Tuesday, Khelif traded blows with her opponent, Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng, in the 66kg weight class semifinal.\n\nWith her win, she is set to compete Friday in the gold medal match.\n\nAfter the official raised her hand to mark her victory, Khelif danced joyfully in the ring as Algerian fans roared their approval.\n\nThe political controversy around Khelif that erupted over the past week centers on a decision last year by the International Boxing Association to disqualify her and another female boxer from some competitions by claiming that they had failed two unspecified gender eligibility tests. The second boxer, Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan, is also competing in the Olympics.\n\nKhelif, 25, is a woman and has competed for years in women's boxing, in which she has accumulated a typical record of wins and losses against her female competition.\n\n\"They were born as girls, registered as female passports, have fought at the senior level for six years with no issues,\" International Olympic Committee spokesperson Mark Adams said on Sunday.\n\nBut the Russia-linked boxing federation has refused to release any details about those tests, and the disqualification was announced shortly after Khelif defeated a Russian boxer.\n\nIn a chaotic press conference Monday, IBA officials raised more questions than they answered about the tests. IBA president Umar Kremlev, speaking by videoconference from Russia, said through a translator that their tests had shown elevated levels of testosterone -- but that claim directly contradicted a previous statement from the IBA that said the boxers had not undergone a testosterone exam.\n\nThe IOC says the IBA shared the results of the test Olympic officials have denounced and continue to defend the boxers' participation.\n\n\"The method of the testing, the idea of the testing -- which kind of happened overnight -- none of it was legitimate,\" Adams said. The IOC broke ties with the IBA last year over long-standing concerns about corruption.\n\nStill, the controversy has led to a swell of harassment online targeted at Khelif and Lin, who will compete in her own semifinal in a different weight class on Wednesday.\n\n\"It can destroy people, it can kill people's thoughts, spirit and mind. It can divide people. And because of that, I ask them to refrain from bullying,\" Khelif said Sunday in an interview with SNTV, a sports news service.\n\nAt the stadium, fans of Algeria said they rejected the claims against Khelif and decried the online harassment that has surrounded her. \"I think she is really brave to get into the ring today despite the relentless campaign against her,\" said Abdelslam Afs. \"We are all here to support her.\"\n\nAnother fan, the Algiers-born Yacine Bouzydy, said he originally hadn't planned to attend Tuesday's bout, as he doesn't closely follow sports. But when he heard about the controversy surrounding Khelif, he decided to attend to show his support and \"give her energy,\" he said.\n\n\"Algeria is quite a conservative country to France and to other European countries. But for this specific story, the role has changed somehow,\" he said.\n\n\"I can imagine that it was very, very hard for her to go beyond this and to compete and to win the bronze medal, at least,\" Bouzydy said. \"I hope it will end with a gold medal. And even if not, Algerian people are very happy.\"", "source": {"uri": "gpb.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Georgia Public Broadcasting"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": this stage and walked out to an electric atmosphere at the converted Roland Garros.\n\nHundreds of flag-waving Algerian supporters turned the normally genteel surroundings of Phillippe-Chatrier Court into a cauldron of noise and chants of \"Imane\" tumbled down from the stands.\n\nAfter a cagey start, Khelif came out on top and shined with a two-shot combination in the first round and was given it resoundingly 5-0 from the judges, all of them scoring it 10-9 in her favour.\n\nThe second round was brighter for Suwannapheng but it was another clean sweep for the Algerian fighter as she used her reach well, putting herself in a very strong position with one round to go.\n\nAs she continued to control things, Khelif cemented her convincing display with her right-hand and uppercut, celebrating {"uri": "8262630907", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "00:25:37", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T00:25:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T00:23:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/paris-olympics-2024/algerian-boxer-imane-khelif-advances-to-gold-medal-match-amid-gender-row/articleshow/112331675.cms", "title": "Algerian boxer Imane Khelif advances to gold medal match amid gender row | Paris Olympics 2024 News - Times of India", "body": "NEW DELHI: Imane Khelif, the Algerian boxer at the center of a significant gender controversy during the Paris Olympics, emerged victorious in her semi-final bout on Tuesday. Competing in the women's 66kg category, Khelif secured at least a silver medal after defeating Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng, the 2023 world silver medallist, by a unanimous points decision.\n\nThe match took place in front of an enthusiastic crowd at Roland Garros, who passionately chanted Khelif's name throughout the contest.\n\nIn a separate weight class, Taiwan's Lin Yu-ting, another boxer involved in the eligibility controversy, is also assured of winning at least a bronze medal. Both Khelif, 25, and Lin participated in the Tokyo Olympics three years prior without any controversy and did not secure medals at that time.\n\nThe two boxers faced disqualification from the world championships last year after failing to meet gender eligibility requirements. However, they were subsequently cleared to participate in the Paris Olympics.\n\n\"I am focusing on the competition and other things are not important. The important thing is that I am in the final now,\" Khelif told BeIN Sports.\n\n\"I am very proud of this new achievement. I gave everything I had. We worked as a team for years and the dream has become a reality. I hope to focus and be up to the responsibility in the dream final.\"\n\nKhelif, the Algerian boxer, received a thunderous ovation as she stepped into the arena at Roland Garros, which is typically known for hosting Grand Slam tennis tournaments.\n\nThe venue was packed with a considerable number of Algerian fans waving flags and chanting \"Imane, Imane\" throughout the bout.\n\nKhelif's opponent, the Thai boxer Janjaem, who was visibly shorter, took a standing count in the third round after feeling the full force of the Algerian's superior skills.\n\nDespite the intense atmosphere, the two fighters showed great sportsmanship at the end of the fight, warmly greeting each other and shaking hands.\n\nKhelif celebrated her victory with a dance in the center of the ring, eliciting even more cheers from the crowd.\n\nShe will face Yang Liu for the gold medal, after the Chinese boxer defeated Taiwan's Chen Nien-chin on points in the other semi-final.\n\nThe gender controversy surrounding Khelif and another boxer, Lin, began when Khelif defeated Angela Carini in just 46 seconds during her opening bout. Carini, who suffered a severe nose injury, was reduced to tears and forced to abandon the fight. The 2023 world championships, from which both Khelif and Lin were expelled, were organized by the International Boxing Association (IBA). However, due to concerns over the IBA's financial, governance, and ethical practices, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) has taken charge of the sport at the Olympic Games.\n\nIBA president Umar Kremlev, who has ties to the Kremlin, made a controversial claim during a chaotic press conference, stating that both fighters had undergone \"genetic testing that shows that these are men.\"\n\nThe IOC has strongly defended Khelif and Lin, with president Thomas Bach emphasizing that they were born and raised as women and hold passports reflecting their gender.\n\nThe TOI Sports Desk excels in a myriad of roles that capture the essence of live sporting events and deliver compelling content to readers worldwide. From running live blogs for India and non-India cricket matches to global spectacles featuring Indian talents, like the Chess World Cup final featuring Praggnanandhaa and the Badminton World Championships semifinal featuring HS Prannoy, our live coverage extends to all mega sporting events. We extensively cover events like the Olympics, Asian Games, Cricket World Cups, FIFA World Cups, and more. The desk is also adept at writing comprehensive match reports and insightful post-match commentary, complemented by stats-based articles that provide an in-depth analysis of player performances and team dynamics. We track news wires for key stories, conduct exclusive player interviews in both text and video formats, and file content from print editions and reporters. We keep track of all viral stories, trending topics and produce our own copies on the subjects. "title": "Algerian boxer at centre of Olympics gender firestorm wins semi, into gold medal bout", "body": "The Algerian boxer embroiled in a major gender controversy at the Paris Olympics won her semi-final on Tuesday to guarantee at least a silver medal in front of a raucous Roland Garros crowd that chanted her name.\n\nImane Khelif defeated Thailand's 2023 world silver medallist Janjaem Suwannapheng in a unanimous points decision to march into Friday's final in the women's 66kg category.\n\nTaiwan's Lin Yu-ting, the other boxer in the eye of a storm over her eligibility, is herself sure to take home at least bronze at a different weight.\n\nMORE OLYMPIC NEWS\n\nTeen's 'all or nothing' gamble and the seven-word message that sparked gold medal stunner\n\nBoomers blow huge lead in brutal Paris heartbreak as Aussie medal bid ends in OT thriller\n\nBreaking down every remaining medal chance for Australia as record in sight\n\n'Never seen anything like it': Star pulls off boilover for the ages in 'ultimate ambush'\n\nThe 25-year-old Khelif and Lin both fought at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago but there was no controversy at the time and neither won a medal.\n\nBoth were disqualified from last year's world championships after failing gender eligibility tests, but were cleared to compete in Paris.\n\nKhelif was given the biggest roar of the night as she entered the arena at Roland Garros, usually home to Grand Slam tennis but hosting Olympic boxing and a sizeable number of Algerian fans with flags.\n\nCries of \"Imane, Imane\" rang out repeatedly before and during the bout. The Thai Janjaem, who had a clear height disadvantage, took a standing count in the third round after feeling the full power of the superior Algerian.\n\nAt the end of the fight at the 15,000-seated Court Philippe-Chatrier, which was close to capacity, the two fighters greeted each other warmly and shook hands.\n\nKhelif did a dance in the middle of the ring, to more roars of approval. She faces Yang Liu for gold after the Chinese boxer beat Taiwan's Chen Nien-chin in the other semi-final on points.\n\nThe gender controversy ignited when Khelif defeated Angela Carini in 46 seconds in her opening bout in the French capital, the Italian reduced to tears and abandoning the fight after suffering a badly hurt nose.\n\nThe 2023 world championships, from which Lin and Khelif were expelled, were run by the International Boxing Association (IBA) but the International Olympic Committee (IOC) is organising the sport at the Games because of financial, governance and ethical concerns at the IBA.\n\nThe IBA's Kremlin-linked president Umar Kremlev claimed at a chaotic press conference on Monday that both fighters had \"genetic testing that shows that these are men\".\n\nThe IOC has leapt to the defence of Khelif and Lin, with president Thomas Bach saying they were born and raised as women, and have passports saying that.\n\nThe 28-year-old Lin fights in the semi-finals I know I'm a talented person and this is a gift to all Algerians.\"\n\nChants of \"Imane\" tumbled down from the stands as Khelif, who is one of two boxers caught up in the ongoing row, dominated Suwannapheng to confirm she will get the chance to emulate compatriot Hocine Soltani, who won lightweight gold in 1996.\n\nThe participation of Khelif and Chinese Taipei featherweight Lin Yu-ting has caused an international storm since Khelif beat Angela Carini of Italy in just 46 seconds in her opening bout last Thursday.\n\nBoth Khelif and Lin were disqualified by the International Boxing Association (IBA) during last year's World Championships for failing to meet gender eligibility criteria.\n\nHowever, the IBA, which was was expelled by the International Olympic Commitee (IOC) over financial and corruption concerns, has failed to provide any proof of its findings.\n\nOn Monday, an IBA press conference descended into farce as controversial president Umar Kremlev made baseless claims about Lin and Khelif and launched an astonishing tirade against IOC president Thomas Bach.\n\nKhelif and Lin were allowed to return to competition by the IOC, which is effectively administering the Paris 2024 boxing tournament in the IBA's absence.\n\nThe case has aroused global interest, with figures such as former United States president Donald Trump and Harry Potter author JK Rowling {"uri": "8262483786", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:28:41", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:28:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:28:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/olympics/news/2024-paris-olympics-imane-khelif-advances-to-gold-medal-fight-with-win-in-semifinals-as-debate-continues/", "title": "2024 Paris Olympics: Imane Khelif advances to gold medal fight with win in semifinals as debate continues - CBSSports.com", "body": "Khelif was in complete control in her win over Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng on Tuesday Getty Images\n\nImane Khelif, whose presence at the Paris Olympics has caused a firestorm of controversy, advanced to the welterweight gold medal fight with her win on Tuesday. Khelif, representing Algeria, took a 5-0 unanimous decision over Janjaem Suwannapheng and will now face the winner of the bout between Nien Chin Chen of Chinese Taipei and Liu Yang of China.\n\nThe bout was not fought at a blistering pace, with Suwannapheng happy to stay outside for the first two rounds, which allowed Kehlif to throw occasional scoring straight punches, mostly a strong jab. Entering the third and final round, Suwannapheng needed an unlikely knockout or knockdown to score the win. Suwannapheng tried to make it more of a fight but was caught by a hard combination and received a standing eight-count, locking up the win for Khelif.\n\nControversy over Khelif's participation reached a fever pitch when she defeated Italy's Angela Carini in just 46 seconds after Carini quit the fight. Social media was soon abuzz with a debate over whether Khelif should be allowed to compete, with some calling her \"a man\" based on a 2023 decision by the IBA to disqualify her and Taiwan's Lin Yu-Ting for failing a \"gender test.\" Khelif defeated Luca Anna Hamori in a standard-looking decision in the quarterfinals, drawing less online chatter than after the Carini fight.\n\nThe IBA, which was dropped by the IOC amid years of controversy and scandal, including findings of fight fixing in the Rio Olympics, has never given clear details about the test though have at various times claimed the tests were not for testosterone but the unspecified test detected XY chromosomes. In a press conference on Monday, IBA officials repeated the XY finding while also suddenly adding that there were issues with Khelif's testosterone levels, this after the previous statements that testosterone tests were not a factor in their previous decision.\n\nIBA president Umar Kremlev also attempted to add fuel to the fire by suggesting during the press conference that Khelif may be a transgender woman, saying, \"I was not present when she was in the Algerian maternity. There is no proof. It may be transgender woman, maybe not.\"\n\nThere is no proof, nor has the IBA ever previously claimed, that Khelif is a transgender woman and photos of her as a young girl have surfaced. She is also a female according to Algeria, where homosexuality as well as gender-affirming surgeries are strictly prohibited by law.\n\nThe IOC has repeatedly stated their position that Khelif is who was roared on by a raucous crowd, won the bout in impressive fashion dominating from start to finish to seal a unanimous decision win.\n\nKhelif even inflicted a standing count on her opponent in the final round.\n\nAnd she danced in the ring after the bout letting out her frustration and excitement.\n\nThe opening round began with Suwannapheng looking good and boxing with confidence early on, as she looked to take the bout to Khelif.\n\nKhelif was not as aggressive as in previous bouts in the first round, but did find her rhythm and was up on the judges' scorecards.\n\nIt was a much faster {"uri": "8262477092", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:21:15", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:21:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:20:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/other-sport/boxing/breaking-imane-khelif-olympics-medal-33409611", "title": "Imane Khelif into gold medal fight amid Olympic boxing gender controversy", "body": "Imane Khelif has reached the Olympic boxing final after beating Janjaem Suwannapheng.\n\nThe Algerian took on her Thai opponent on Tuesday evening in Paris having already guaranteed herself at least a bronze medal. And she could earn even more having found a route past Suwannapheng.\n\nKhelif dominated throughout the opening two rounds of the bout. She won every judge's scorecard from the first round, and after landing a few impressive hits in the second, did exactly the same.\n\nSuwannapheng had to go for broke in the final round buit failed to knockout her opponent, which allowed Khelif to waltz to victory. She now heads into Friday's final and will take on either Chen Nien-chin or Yang Liu.\n\nKhelif has been at the heart of ongoing controversy at the Olympics. Her opening round fight with Italian rival Angela Carini was abandoned after less than a minute.\n\nThat led to many questioning her eligibility in the championships - particularly in the wake of the International Boxing Association disqualifying her from competition in 2023. Khelif was one of two female fighters to fail an unspecified gender test during last year's world championships in Delhi.\n\nHowever, the IBA are no longer recognised as amateur boxing's governing body due to concerns over finances, governance, ethics, refereeing and judging. And due to the International Olympic Committee having different eligibility criteria, she was free to fight in Paris.\n\nKhelif, 25, beat Carini in her opening round before overcoming Anna Luca Hamori in the quarter-finals. Speaking ahead of her semi-final clash with Suwannapheng, she asked for empathy and for her critics to refrain from the incredible levels of hostility directed towards her.\n\n\"I send a message to all the people of the world to uphold the Olympic principles and the Olympic Charter, to refrain from bullying all athletes, because this has effects, massive effects.\n\n\"It can destroy people, it can kill people's thoughts, spirit and mind. It can divide people. And because of that, I ask them to refrain from bullying.\n\n\"I am in contact with my family two days a week. I hope that they weren't affected deeply. They are worried about me. God willing, this crisis will culminate in a gold medal, and that would be the best response.\"\n\nKhelif's latest success comes after IBA president Umar Kremlev launched a bizarre rant at both her and Lin-Yu ting, who had also failed a gender test. Speaking in a press conference, he said: \"The tests show they were men.\n\n\"We don't verify what they have between their legs. We don't know if they were born like that, or if some changes were made. The second tests confirmed the first tests. If people have doubts, refer to them. They can make their own tests.\"\n\nKhelif's Dad has also attempted to intervene over the last few days. According to Mail Online, he shared a document that confirmed his daughter had been born a female.\n\nHer semi-final opponent Suwannapheng had said before the bout: \"Imane is a little girl that has loved sport since she was six-years-old, she used to play football. These critics and rumours aim to destabilise Imane, they don't want her to be the champion of the world.\n\n\"I tell her prove them wrong in the ring and I hope that she will honour Algeria and Arabic countries and win the gold medal. She is our role model, and we want to be like her and honour Algeria and Tiaret.\"\n\nFollow all the action on day 11 of the Paris Olympics with Mirror Sport's live blog", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8262313653", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "18:46:17", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T18:46:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T18:45:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/imane-khelif-vs-janjaem-suwannapheng-183520768.html", "title": "Imane Khelif vs Janjaem Suwannapheng Olympic boxing live updates, results, highlights", "body": "PARIS - Algeria's Imane Khelif is back in the boxing ring tonight at the Paris Olympics. And this time under the lights at Roland Garros Stadium. Khelif is fighting for a chance to win a silver or gold medal.\n\nKhelif has advanced to the semifinals of the welterweight division (146 pounds). She'll be facing a familiar foe - Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng. Khelif, 25, beat Suwannapheng in the semifinals of the 2023 world championships before Khelif was disqualified for allegedly failing what the organizers called a \"gender eligibility test.\"\n\nThe International Boxing Association (IBA), a discredited organization with no role in the Olympics, disqualified Khelif and Taiwanese boxer Lin without providing evidence of any failed tests. Lin is scheduled to fight in her semifinal match Wednesday.\n\nA victory for Khelif would vault her into the finals, where the winner would win gold and the runner-up would take silver. But she's already guaranteed bronze.\n\nIn Olympic boxing, bronze medals are awarded to both losing semifinalists in the single-elimination format tournament.\n\nBouts are scheduled for three rounds and are scored by five judges. Using a 10-point system, each judge awards 10 points to the boxer they deem won the round and at least nine points to the boxer they deem lost the round.\n\nBarring a stoppage, the winner of the bout will be determined by points based on the judges' scorecards. A boxer earns one point for each judge who deems the boxer has won at least two of the three rounds.\n\nIn Khelif's opening bout, Italy's Angela Carini abandoned the fight only 46 seconds into the match. Khelif demonstrated she could deliver a punch - one solidly connected with Carini's face before the Italian quit fighting - and Khelif secured a spot in the quarterfinals.\n\nIn Khelif's quarterfinal bout, she beat Hungary's Anna Luca Hamori on points by unanimous decision, 5-0. This time she had nine minutes to perform and showed impressive boxing skills in dominating Hamori.\n\nKhelif, who made her amateur boxing debut in 2018, is 38-9 with five knockouts as an amateur, according to BoxRec.\n\nThe 23-year-old won her first two bouts by split decision. The victories came against Brigitte Mbabi of the Democratic Republic of The Congo and Busenaz Surmeneli of Turkey.\n\nShe made her amateur boxing debut in 2019 and is 14-5 with one knockout, according {"uri": "8262584977", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "23:26:46", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T23:26:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T23:25:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/08/06/boxer-in-controversy-over-eligibility-lets-her-gloves-do-the-talking/", "title": "Boxer in Controversy Over Eligibility Lets Her Gloves Do the Talking", "body": "An Olympic boxing competition that briefly seemed to be about questions about gender, eligibility and international politics proved on Tuesday to be simply about sports, with one fighter beating another without inquiry or controversy.\n\nImane Khelif of Algeria, the boxer whose eligibility was questioned after her first-round victory and then vigorously defended by the International Olympic Committee, won her weight division's semifinal bout by unanimous decision. She will fight for a gold medal at the Paris Games on Friday.\n\nKhelif beat her opponent, Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand, through precise and effective striking and quick footwork. After the result was announced, she celebrated in the middle of the ring, joyfully raising her hand.\n\n\"I am very happy,\" she said through an interpreter, standing with the red, green and white Algerian flag draped on her shoulders. \"I've worked eight years for these Olympics and I'm very proud of this moment.\" The Algerian president, Abdelmadjid Tebboune, congratulated Khelif on social media.\n\nThe uproar surrounding Khelif, 25, had its roots at last year's boxing world championships in India, where she and another boxer, Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan, were ruled ineligible to compete after they underwent unspecified blood tests. The International Boxing Association, which ran the tournament and disqualified the fighters, never fully explained its decisions, saying that Khelif and Lin \"did not undergo a testosterone examination but were subject to a separate and recognized test.\"\n\nThe International Olympic Committee, which no longer recognizes the I.B.A. as boxing's governing authority, allowed Khelif and Lin to compete in the Paris Games, saying their disqualifications in 2023 had been \"sudden and arbitrary,\" and that \"every person has the right to practice sport without discrimination.\" The I.O.C. said plainly that the boxers are women. Lin will fight in the semifinal of her weight division on Wednesday.\n\nIn her first bout, Khelif defeated Angela Carini of Italy, who quit just 46 seconds into the fight after absorbing a powerful blow to the face. Later, she sobbed and told reporters she had \"never felt a punch like this.\" Khelif's eligibility was questioned, including by the British author J.K. Rowling and the billionaire Elon Musk. Giorgia Meloni, Italy's prime minister, told reporters, \"Athletes who have male genetic characteristics should not be admitted to female competitions.\"\n\nCarini has since apologized to Khelif, telling an Italian media outlet, \"All this controversy certainly made me sad.\" Khelif, in an interview with the news service SNTV, denounced the treatment she's received and thanked the I.O.C. for its support.\n\n\"I send a message to all the people of the world to uphold the Olympic principles and the Olympic charter, to refrain from bullying all athletes, because this has effects, massive effects,\" Khelif said in Arabic. \"It can destroy people, it can kill people's thoughts, spirit and mind. It can divide people. And because of that, I ask them to refrain from bullying.\"\n\nIn a chaotic news conference on Monday, officials of the I.B.A. offered no documentation for their decision to suspend the two fighters. The two athletes have been cleared to compete in Paris.\n\nHowever, the row began ramping up when Khelif faced-off against Italy's Angela Carini in the round of 16 last Thursday (1 August).\n\nCarini said she was forced to abandon the match after just 46 seconds because she had never been hit so hard in her life.\n\nShe said: \"It hurt so much. I am heartbroken.\n\n\"I went to the ring to honour my father. I was told a lot of times that I was a warrior, but I preferred to stop for my health. have failed gender eligibility tests.\n\nAmid wild support under the roof of Court Philippe Chatrier - the French tennis venue repurposed for the boxing finals - Khelif dominated her Thai opponent to win by unanimous decision.\n\nIt secured progression to her first Olympic final, having been knocked out in the quarter-finals in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nShe will fight Taiwanese Chen Nien-chin or Liu Yang of China in the gold-medal bout.\n\nAlgeria has never won a boxing gold medal.\n\nKhelif beat Suwannapheng by unanimous decision at last year's World Championships, before being disqualified by the IBA.\n\nHere, the crowd chanted her name as she entered the ring - and the Algerian looked more confident than she had at any point this week.\n\nAfter the result was confirmed she dropped her guard and danced on the canvas, and a bout fought in good spirits ended with an embrace between the two fighters.\n\nKhelif's Games began with a win against Angela Carini last week - a fight that And she could earn even more having found a route past Suwannapheng.\n\nKhelif dominated throughout the opening two rounds of the bout. She won every judge's scorecard from the first round, and after landing a few impressive hits in the second, did exactly the same.\n\nSuwannapheng had to go for broke in the final round buit failed to knockout her opponent, which allowed Khelif to waltz to victory. She now heads into Friday's final and will take on either Chen Nien-chin or Yang Liu.\n\nKhelif has been at the heart of ongoing controversy at the Olympics. Her opening round fight with Italian rival Angela Carini was abandoned after less than a minute.\n\nThat led to many questioning her eligibility in the championships - particularly in the wake of the International Boxing Association disqualifying her from competition in 2023. Khelif was one of two female fighters to fail an unspecified gender test during last year's world championships in Delhi.\n\nHowever, the IBA are no longer recognised as amateur boxing's governing body due to concerns over finances, governance, ethics, refereeing and judging. And due to the International Olympic Committee having different eligibility criteria, she was free to fight in Paris.\n\nKhelif, 25, beat Carini in her opening round before overcoming Anna Luca Hamori in the quarter-finals. Speaking ahead of her semi-final clash with Suwannapheng, she asked for empathy and for her critics to refrain from the incredible levels of hostility directed towards her.\n\n\"I send a message to all the people of the world to uphold the Olympic principles and the Olympic Charter, to refrain from bullying all athletes, because this has effects, massive effects.\n\n\"It can destroy people, it can kill people's thoughts, spirit and mind. It can divide people. And because of that, I ask them to refrain from bullying.\n\n\"I am in contact with my family two days a week. I hope that they weren't affected deeply. They are worried about me. God willing, this crisis will culminate in a gold medal, and that would be the best response.\"\n\nKhelif's latest success comes after IBA president Umar Kremlev launched a bizarre rant at both her and Lin-Yu ting, who had also failed a gender test. Speaking in a press conference, he said: \"The tests show they were men.\n\n\"We don't verify what they have between their legs. We don't know if they were born like that, or if some changes were made. The second tests confirmed the first tests. If people have doubts, refer to them. They can make their own tests.\"\n\nKhelif's Dad has also attempted to intervene over the last few days. with another dominant performance in a one-sided semi-final at Roland Garros.\n\nKhelif, 25, was banned from last year's World Championships by Russian-led governing body IBA after failing a gender test shortly before she was due to fight for a gold medal.\n\nAccording to the IBA, which was stripped of the right to run boxing at the Games amid corruption and governance issues, she was found to have the male 'XY' chromosome.\n\nHowever, no such tests have been carried out at the Games, with eligibility based around what sex is listed in a participant's passport.\n\nAlgerian boxer Imane Khelif beat Janjaem Suwannapheng on points to secure a place in the Olympic final and guarantee herself a medal at the 2024 Games in Paris\n\nThe 25-year-old Algerian boxer won the bout (pictured above) via unanimous decision\n\nKhelif, who had a two inch height advantage, was roared on by a noisy Algerian contingent and who has now won 12 straight bouts, will return to the tennis landmark, which has taken over from the North Paris Arena for the latter stages of the boxing, on Friday night.\n\nShe overpowered her plucky opponent, landed the bigger shots and cruised to victory with a unanimous verdict that will have done little to quiet down those who say she should not be here.\n\nThe situation is likely to cause a continued headache for IOC bosses, who have been forced to defend Khelif's presence in Paris on an almost-daily basis.\n\nThe second boxer who failed a gender test at the same competition, Taiwan's Lin Yu-Ting, fights her semi-final tonight (WED) against Turkey's Khelif at the Paris Olympics.\n\nJanjaem Suwannapheng is a Thai amateur boxer born on September 25, 2000.\n\nShe has made significant strides in her boxing career, earning a medal at the 2023 AIBA Women's World Boxing Championships.\n\nJanjaem competes in the 66 kg (welterweight) category.\n\nHer achievements on the international stage include representing Thailand at the Paris Olympics.\n\nRemarkably, she became the first athlete from Nong Khai, her small province in northeastern Thailand, to compete in the Olympics.\n\nDuring the games, she showcased her skills by defeating Brigitte Mbabi from Congo in the round of 16, despite a challenging start where she was knocked down early in the match.\n\nShe continued her impressive performance by overcoming the Turkish number-one seed, Busenaz S\u00fcrmeneli, in the quarter-finals.\n\nJanjaem also serves in the Royal Thai Air Force with the rank of leading aircraft woman.\n\nJanjaem Suwannapheng will fight Imane Khelif in the women's 66kg semi-final at the Paris Olympics on Tuesday, August 6, at 9:34 PM.\n\nThe winner will advance to the final, which will take place on Friday, August 9.\n\nKhelif's recent match against Angela Carini ignited widespread debate over Khelif's gender.\n\nCarini forfeited the bout after just 46 seconds, citing what she described as an unfair disadvantage.\n\nIOC President Thomas Bach voiced his support for Imane Khelif, who was disqualified by the IBA in 2023 due to alleged eligibility issues.\n\nHe said: \"Let's be very clear here: We are discussing women's boxing.\n\n\"Both Khelif and Lin are individuals who were born female, raised as women, hold passports identifying them as women, and have competed as women for many years.\n\n\"This unequivocally defines them as women, and there has never been any doubt about their gender.\"\n\nAhead of their semi-final bout, Janjaem Suwannapheng has shared her thoughts on facing Imane Khelif.\n\nShe told Thai newspaper Khaosod: \"I've researched her thoroughly and know that she's faced losses to female boxers in the past, though that was some time ago.\n\n\"I'm uncertain if she's grown stronger or if there have been changes in her hormonal levels.\n\n\"However, I'm not intimidated by the prospect of meeting her again because I believe we're evenly matched.\n\n\"I've dedicated myself to rigorous training and prepared my body well. Ultimately, strength and resilience aside, we're both human and equipped with two fists.\n\n\"Having come this far, I'm determined to push through to win the gold medal.\"\n\nSuwannapheng had previously lost to Khelif in India in 2023.\n\nShe said her loss was due to exhaustion and her menstrual cycle at the time.", "source": {"uri": "thesun.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Sun"}, Suwannapheng was pounded with punches in the third round and took a standing eight-count.\n\nThus far in the Paris Olympics, Khelif has won every single round on every judge's card.\n\nKhelif and Lin Yu\u2011ting of Taiwan both failed gender tests in 2019 and 2023, per the International Boxing Association (IBA).\n\nA blood test in 2019 showed that the fighters had \"inconsistent\" results, suggesting that the bloodwork was inconsistent with that of a female, IBA CEO Chris Roberts said during a press conference on Monday. In 2023, another test revealed that the fighters \"demonstrated the chromosomes we refer to in competition rules that make both boxers ineligible,\" he added.\n\nKhelif and Lin were subsequently disqualified from the 2023 world championships. Notably, Suwannapheng and Khelif fought during the tournament before Khelif's disqualification. Khelif won that match, too.\n\nWATCH THE TRAILER FOR 'AM I RACIST?' -- A MATT WALSH COMEDY ON DEI\n\nOpponents of Khelif and Lin have spoken out about having to fight the boxers. {"uri": "8262567744", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "23:05:53", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T23:05:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T23:04:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/imane-khelif-continues-quest-boxing-225925534.html", "title": "Imane Khelif continues quest for boxing gold with semi-final victory", "body": "Imane Khelif's \u00adextraordinary Olympic Games still has one round left to run. At a wild, steamy, increasingly unbound Roland Garros, Algeria's fifth seed outclassed Janjaem Suwannapheng of Thailand to win the women's 66kg semi-final bout and set up a final against Yang Liu of China on Friday.\n\nThis was a startling event in so many ways, in large part here because of its exuberantly \u00adAlgerian tone. The snaking queue outside Roland Garros in the hours before this \u00adevening round of Olympic \u00adboxing had been heavily stacked with Algerian flags and football shirts. Centre court, reconfigured into a breathtaking boxing area, was similarly decked with the red and green.\n\nRelated: The men of international boxing use the Olympics to spoil for another kind of fight\n\nThis has been one effect of the controversy around Khelif. The \u00adAlgerian diaspora in Paris has come out in numbers to \u00adsupport her, a reflection of the way the events of the past two weeks have been received back home.\n\nIt has been another \u00adextraordinary week in this story, with Khelif and Lin Yu-ting of Chinese Taipei guaranteed a medal of some sort \u00adhaving both reached their semi-finals (two bronzes are awarded in boxing, in keeping with the sport's most basic code that \u00adanyone who gets in the ring deserves something just for doing so).\n\nBoth boxers have been at the centre of Paris 2024's most fevered and bruising extra-sport story, which was aggravated further this week by the chaotic short-notice press conference staged in a Paris hotel by the International Boxing Federation.\n\nIt was of course the IBA that banned both Khelif and Lin from competing during the world championships last year on the basis of swab and blood tests that suggested neither was qualified to take part in the women's event.\n\nKhelif and Suwannapheng entered the arena at 10.25pm, by which time the Algerian flags were everywhere, rippling and waving in every corner. Suwannapheng got plenty of cheers from the Thai crowd. Khelif emerged to ear-mangling whistles, the \u00adAlgerian supporters dancing in the aisles and chanting: \"Imane, Imane!\"\n\nThere was an odd circularity to this Olympic semi-final - of course, because this is now high drama - as Khelif versus Suwannapheng was in effect a rematch of the world championship bout, won by Khelif, that preceded her disqualification.\n\nSuwannapheng had beaten the reigning gold medallist and favourite Busenaz Surmeneli on her way here. She has blistering foot speed and was in and out of range to good effect early on, coming in behind Khelif's jab.\n\nKhelif was the taller boxer with a greater reach. She likes to keep her distance and tag her opponent with the jab or come in with the long straight right. It was messy at times, a clash of \u00admethods, all flailing arms and \u00adbumping in the clinches, but Khelif took the opening round 10-9 on every card.\n\nRoland Garros has taken over from the North Paris Arena business park complex as the venue for these finals, which is a bit like moving from a cheerful old clanky National League ground to the Augusta National Golf Club. It is a wonderful space, every soft touch surface beautifully turned, the roof creating a boisterous echo chamber, but also a sweat-box effect that left trainers furiously fanning their charges with towels between rounds.\n\nSuwannapheng needed to get closer in the second, but struggled to evade the jab. Khelif reeled off a couple of powerful uppercuts and never really came under enough pressure, taking it by the same score.\n\nSuwannapheng had no choice but to up her work rate and get closer in the third, but by now Roland \u00adGarros was in a state of pre\u2011celebratory uproar, every combination cheered. A \u00adstanding count for \u00adSuwannapheng shortly before the end drew a great \u00adwhooshing wave of noise. As the \u00addecision was announced Khelif wagged her finger and strolled around the ring as the stands re-erupted, then returned to do a knees-up style dance of joy.\n\nAfterwards she was once again assailed by the gathered global media in surely one of the most fevered Olympic boxing mixed zones ever staged, stopping this time to talk to Algerian TV, looking calm, unmarked and delighted to have progressed this far. For reasons that stretch far beyond the distribution of a featherweight gold medal, that final really is going to be quite an event.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8262537949", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:28:38", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:28:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T22:27:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5685067/2024/08/06/imane-khelif-olympic-boxing-results/", "title": "Algerian boxer Khelif advances to gold medal round", "body": "PARIS -- When it was over, when her arm had been raised and the gloves had been touched, Imane Khelif soaked up the roars of the crowd and ran in giddy little steps around the ring inside the tennis cathedral turned boxing ring.\n\nThe Algerian fighter's jubilant celebration to mark her achievement of reaching the Olympic final stood in contrast to her reaction three days ago, when her quarterfinal win reduced her to tears on the mat, overcome with emotion from a week that has seen her gender questioned amid the still-unclear circumstances that led to her disqualification from a major fight last year.\n\nBut Tuesday, she had assured herself at least a silver medal, beating Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng in a unanimous decision inside Court Philippe Chatrier at the Roland Garros tennis facility, converted to host boxing for the remainder of the Games.\n\nShe will face China's Yang Liu in the 66-kilogram final Friday night.\n\nKhelif has been caught in a global frenzy over the past week after a swift end to her round-of-16 match against Italy's Angela Carini brought renewed attention to the circumstances of her disqualification from the 2023 world championships. Carini quit the bout just 46 seconds in after taking hard punches.\n\nA year ago, the International Boxing Association, which runs the world championships, banned Khelif and another fighter, Taiwan's Lin Yu-ting, in the middle of that tournament after they said that tests had shown them to have \"competitive advantages over other female competitors.\"\n\nBoth Khelif and Lin were assigned female at birth and have always competed in women's divisions. The IBA has provided no further clarification of its decision, and even confused things further Monday as officials made contradictory descriptions of the tests while saying they could not disclose the actual results.\n\nLin will fight in the 57-kilogram semifinals on Wednesday.\n\nThe IOC, which runs the Olympic tournament, has repeatedly supported Khelif and Lin's inclusion.\n\n\"They are eligible by the rules of the federation which was set in 2016, and which worked for Tokyo too,\" where Khelif and Lin also competed, IOC spokesman Mark Adams said last week. \"To compete as women, which is what they are. And we fully support that.\"\n\nKhelif, her coach and others in the boxing community have dismissed the IBA's decision as baseless.\n\n\"They (boxing authorities) did some worthless tests, tests that don't show anything,\" Mohamed Chaoua, Khelif's coach, told SNTV and the Associated Press.\n\n\"She will box, and she will fight,\" said Roumaysa Boualam, Khelif's teammate on the Algerian boxing team. \"This is unfair, what's happened. ... We have to support her.\"\n\nAfter her bout with Khelif, Carini did not participate in the customary post-match handshake, which inflamed speculation about her feelings on fighting Khelif. Carini later apologized in an interview with an Italian publication, Gazzetta dello Sport.\n\n\"It was not intentional, in fact, I apologize to her and to everyone,\" Carini said. \"I was angry because my Games had already gone up in smoke. I have nothing against Khelif and, on the contrary, if I happened to meet her again I would give her a hug.\"\n\nTwo days later, Khelif beat Hungary's Anna Luca Hamori in the quarterfinals. After that match, a Hungarian IOC representative, Bal\u00e1zs F\u00fcrjes, delivered prepared remarks that did little to stamp down the controversy.\n\n\"We are not afraid of difficult circumstances and are ready to fight even among difficult circumstances,\" F\u00fcrjes said. \"... We are 100 percent convinced that the International Olympic Committee will make the right decisions.\"\n\nNow, Khelif is into the Olympic final, set for Friday at Roland Garros, and one step from a The Algerian successfully clinched Suwannapheng on several attempts, clearly subduing the Thai boxer with superior strength.\n\nThe Algerian became the talk of the Paris Summer Games after rocking the opposition, Italian boxer Angela Carini, so hard with a punch that Carini began crying and quit the match.\n\nCarini later apologized for her display of emotion and for spotlighting Khelif's failed gender test.\n\nKhelif's past opponents have also made clear references to the boxer's lack of verification for XX chromosomes, which gets the debate going on why someone who is naturally beyond the physical capabilities of a typical woman has been permitted to fight against women.\n\nAs reported by OutKick's Mark Harris, Khelif has already secured a bronze medal in women's boxing yet surges on. Fellow contested boxer Taiwan's Lin Yu-Ting is also dominating competitions against women who have no issue confirming whether they have XX chromosomes. Khelif and Yu-Ting were removed from the Women's World Boxing Championship in March 2023.\n\nREAD: Second Olympic Boxer Who Failed Gender Test Takes Down Another Female Fighter\n\nBased on the cheers for Khelif on Tuesday, viewers could assume that this match was just like any other. Instead, Khelif's dominant win suggests that further evaluation is needed to determine what sets these competitors' heads and shoulders (bulky ones, too) above the rest of the pool.\n\nAs the International Olympic Committee (IOC) continually repeats that boxers such as Khelif and Lin meet all requirements, the tale of the tape suggests a different story.\n\nKhelif advances to the final,
