{"uri": "8262504146", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:53:03", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:53:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:51:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://nybreaking.com/imane-khelifs-health-is-at-the-center-of-controversy-over-boxing-at-the-2024-olympics-heres-what-we-think-of-her-female-fighters/", "title": "Imane Khelif's Health Is At The Center Of Controversy Over Boxing At The 2024 Olympics - Here's What We Think Of Her Female Fighters - Ny Breaking News", "body": "The controversy surrounding Olympic boxer Imane Khelif grew even bigger tonight after she defeated a Thai woman in a landslide to advance to the final.\n\nThere have been calls to ban the 1.78m Khelif, 25 years old and one win shy of Olympic gold, from competing, suggesting she is not biologically female.\n\nShe is not transgender - there are photos of her as a little girl - and according to Olympic organizers, the Algerian has passed all gender eligibility checks.\n\nHowever, last year Khelif was disqualified from the world championships by the Russian governing body IBA after she failed a gender test just before she was due to compete for a gold medal.\n\nSome health experts believe she may have a disorder of sex development (DSD), an umbrella term for individuals with a group of conditions in which their reproductive anatomy does not conform to the typical definition of male or female.\n\nKhelif denies this.\n\nDailyMail.com spoke to two women born with DSDs -- and to doctors -- about whether they think Khelif has an unfair advantage over her female opponents.\n\nImane Khelif celebrates her victory over Thai boxer Janjaem Suwannapheng today\n\nKhelif faces controversy over her candidacy in women's boxing\n\nHannah Twigg is an intersex woman from the United Kingdom who suffers from a condition called Complete Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (CAIS).\n\nThis means that although she has the XY chromosomes of a male, her body does not respond to testosterone because of a genetic mutation.\n\nAs a result, she has developed feminine characteristics, as testosterone has no effect on her sexual development.\n\nMs Twigg said: 'I was on a lot of sports teams in high school and played myself.\n\n'(But) I've never felt like my condition gave me an advantage or disadvantage in sports.'\n\nShe added: \"I would like to take this opportunity to say that Imane Khelif does not owe anyone an explanation for her gender and identity.\"\n\nBecause testosterone is not acting on her body, this means she has not experienced the increase in muscle mass that men experience during puberty.\n\nAfter puberty, men have about 40 to 50 percent more muscle mass than women.\n\nHowever, some experts claim that Khelif may have another condition called 5-Alpha-Reductase Deficiency (5-ARD).\n\nIn this case, an individual is biologically male - with XY chromosomes - but his body fails to respond to a crucial hormone in the womb, leading to the development of a vagina or indeterminate external genitalia.\n\nHowever, inside they have undescended testicles, which begin to release testosterone once a person reaches puberty. This leads to the development of male characteristics, including an increase in muscle mass.\n\nSouth African middle-distance runner Caster Semenya was previously diagnosed with the condition, which led to her being disqualified from athletics competitions due to her elevated testosterone levels.\n\nIt is estimated that approximately one to two in every 100 people in the US are born with an intersex gender, or DSD.\n\nIntersex women have defended Khelif, saying she should be allowed to compete in her category because she is a woman. Pictured on the left is Alyssa Ball, an activist for the intersex community, and on the right is Hannah Twigg, an intersex woman from the UK who is raising awareness about the condition.\n\nKhelif was forced to speak out earlier this week, calling on boxing fans to stop bullying the athletes\n\nKhelif, who was registered as female at birth, has been at the centre of a gender row after the IBA disqualified her from the world championships last year. She is pictured at the Paris Olympics\n\nAlyssa Ball, who is also intersex and campaigns for awareness of the condition, told DailyMail.com: 'I feel quite emotionally drained talking about this topic.\n\n'As an intersexual person, I naturally think she should be allowed to participate.\n\n\"Whatever 'advantages' she has, they are comparable to those of anyone else who is born with a body shape best suited for any sport.\"\n\nHowever, Dr Tommy Lundberg, a lecturer in physiology at Sweden's Karolinska Institute, disagreed, arguing that she probably had a biological advantage because she had probably gone through male puberty.\n\nHe said: 'If Khelif is indeed on 5-ARD, then that would be considered male development during puberty and therefore an advantage.\n\n'Being male is not a talent and should not be rewarded more than being female.\n\n\"Including athletes with male performance advantages in women's sports violates the very important principles of fair and safe competition for female athletes.\"\n\nIn tonight's match, Khelif defeated her rival Janjaem Suwannapheng after overpowering the brave opponent and delivering harder blows, eventually winning by unanimous decision.\n\nThe testosterone limit rules had previously been brought into sharp focus by Caster Semenya, who was banned from women's athletics competitions after she was found to have elevated testosterone levels.\n\nShe was cheered by a noisy Algerian crowd, who were already chanting 'Imane' before their boxer entered the arena.\n\nAfter winning, she skipped victoriously around the arena before leaving to loud cheers ahead of her gold medal match on Friday.\n\nFiona McAnena, who works with scientists who research sex differences and is director of the UK women's sport charity Sex Matters, also said she was likely at an advantage.\n\nShe said: 'It is not the fault of these young people that they have a congenital (developmental) defect and are registered as female, while their chromosomes are male. This can be a shocking, surprising and even traumatic thing to discover.\n\nBut apart from that, women's sports are meant for people who have a female advantage and not a male advantage.\n\n\"If athletes have a male advantage and have gone through male puberty, then they do not belong in women's sports.\"\n\nKhelif's condition has not been made public. Experts can only speculate on whether she has a condition, and if so, what it is.\n\nBut a recent change in the International Olympic Committee's (IOC) statement suggests she may be intersex.\n\nOn August 3, they updated a statement saying \"this is not a Discrimination in Sexual Development issue\" to \"this is not a transgender issue.\"\n\nKhelif herself has said that she is a woman and has promised to continue competing.\n\nIn a statement, she said: \"I am sending my message to all people around the world to adhere to the Olympic principles, as per the Olympic Charter, and to avoid bullying of athletes, as this has a major impact.\n\n\"It can destroy people, kill people's thinking and spirit, and divide people.\"\n\nShe previously dismissed the decision to ban her from the IBA competition as a \"conspiracy\" to prevent an Algerian from winning.\n\nIn Khelif's native Algeria, there are strict anti-LGBT laws and society does not tolerate transgender people.\n\nThe IOC interprets someone's gender literally based on what is stated in the passport.\n\nThey also organise the women's boxing competition, despite a separate dispute with the IBA, which was barred from involvement.\n\nHowever, in other categories, such as swimming, the federation reserves the right to test athletes if there are concerns they may have a biological advantage.\n\nExperts suggest that the same thing should happen in boxing. They say that a blood test can determine whether someone has gone through male puberty. {"uri": "2024-08-446224567", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "22:29:09", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T22:29:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T18:18:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/aug/6/imane-khelif-sex-disputed-olympic-boxer-advances-t/", "title": "Sex-disputed boxer Imane Khelif advances to Olympic gold-medal round after women's semifinal win", "body": "Imane Khelif, an Algerian boxer whose biological sex has been questioned, defeated Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng in the Olympic women's welterweight semifinals, a victory that keeps alive the fighter's gold-medal hopes -- and adds more fuel to the ongoing uproar over fairness in female sports.\n\nKhelif, 25, won a unanimous decision Tuesday against the 23-year-old Suwannapheng in the 145 lb. (66 kg.) division, advancing to the Friday championship match with a guarantee of Olympic silver at minimum.\n\nThe win drew further attention to the international debate over the fighter's gender status and the International Olympic Committee's eligibility standards fpr women's boxing, a story that has dominated the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nKhelif is one of two athletes competing in Paris despite being disqualified at the 2023 Women's World Championships in New Delhi, where blood tests showed they failed to meet the gender criteria, according to the International Boxing Association.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee has defended the boxers' participation, saying they complied with the eligibility rules and that \"they are women on their passport.\"\n\n\"Let's be very clear here,\" said IOC President Thomas Bach last weekend. \"We are talking about women's boxing. We have two boxers who were born as women, have been raised as women, who have a passport as a woman, and who have competed for many years as a woman. And this is the clear definition of a woman.\"\n\nThe second boxer, Lin Yu-ting of Taiwan, is scheduled to fight Wednesday in the women's featherweight bout in the 126 lb. (57 kg.) weight class.\n\nComplicating the matter is the bad blood between the IOC and IBA. The IOC dropped the association as its boxing authority last year over concerns about finances, governance and judging integrity, replacing it with an ad hoc Paris 2024 unit.\n\nThe IOC has insisted that \"this is not a transgender issue,\" spurring speculation that the fighters may have a Difference of Sexual Development known as 46, XY, which results in ambiguous genitalia at birth but male-level testosterone levels after puberty.\n\nAmar Khelif, the fighter's father, told Reuters that his child is a girl, citing an \"official family document\" showing the newborn's sex listed as \"female.\"\n\n\"Having such a daughter is an honor because she is a champion, she honored me and I encourage her and I hope she will get the medal in Paris,\" he said. \"Imane is a little girl that has loved sport since she was six years old.\"\n\nThe Algerian Olympic and Sports Committee has filed a complaint over online harassment directed at its boxer, while advocates for fairness in women's sports have blasted the Olympic rules allowing the boxers to compete without resolving the gender questions.\n\nLinda Blade, a Canadian athlete, coach and advocate for single-sex female sports, said the match \"reinforces the need for the sex screen.\"\n\n\"If we cannot screen for biological sex, there is no way to know what is happening or if one of the fighters has a categorial advantage,\" she {"uri": "8262499203", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-06", "time": "21:45:33", "dateTime": "2024-08-06T21:45:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-06T21:44:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-13715289/imane-khelif-olympics-womens-boxing-condition.html", "title": "We have the same condition as Khelif. Here's what we think", "body": "The controversy surrounding Olympian boxer Imane Khelif was amplified tonight after she emphatically beat a Thai woman and advanced to the finals.\n\nThere have been calls for the 5ft 10in Khelif, 25, who is now one win away from Olympic gold, to be banned from competing due to a suggestion she may not be biologically female.\n\nShe is not transgender -- there are photos from her childhood as a little girl -- and Olympic organizers say the Algerian passed all gender eligibility checks.\n\nHowever, Khelif was disqualified from last year's World Championships by Russian-led governing body IBA after failing a gender test shortly before she was due to fight for a gold medal.\n\nSome health experts believe she has a differences in sex development (DSD) disorder, an umbrella term for individuals who have a group of conditions where their reproductive anatomy does not match the typical definition of male or female.\n\nKhelif denies this.\n\nDailyMail.com spoke to two women born with DSDs -- plus doctors -- about whether they think Khelif has an unfair advantage over her female opponents.\n\nImane Khelif pictured celebrating her victory over Thai boxer Janjaem Suwannapheng today\n\nKhelif is facing controversy over her candidacy in the women's boxing\n\nHannah Twigg is an intersex woman from the UK who has a condition called Complete Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (CAIS).\n\nIt means that although she has the XY chromosomes of a male, her body does not respond to testosterone because of a genetic mutation.\n\nAs a result, she has developed the traits of a female -- because testosterone has no effect on her sex development.\n\nMs Twigg said: 'I was involved a lot in sports teams in high school, playing on sports teams.\n\nRead More What is a DSD? The condition at the heart of the Olympic boxing controversy\n\n'[But] I never felt as though my condition gave me an advantage or disadvantage in sport.'\n\nShe added: 'I would like to take the opportunity to say that Imane Khelif does not owe anyone an explanation for her gender and identity.'\n\nBecause testosterone does not act on her body, this means she has not gone through the surge in muscle mass that males experience at puberty.\n\nAfter puberty, men have about 40 to 50 percent more muscle mass than women.\n\nSome experts suggest Khelif may have a different condition, however, called 5-Alpha-Reductase Deficiency (5-ARD).\n\nIn this, an individual is biologically male -- with XY chromosomes -- but their body does not respond to a crucial hormone in the womb, leading to the development of a vagina or indeterminate sex organs externally.\n\nInternally, however, they have undescended testicles, which start to release testosterone when someone hits puberty -- leading to the development of male characteristics including a surge in muscle mass.\n\nPreviously, the South African mid-distance runner Caster Semenya was diagnosed with the condition -- which led her to be barred from track events because of elevated testosterone levels.\n\nEstimates suggest about one to two out of every 100 people in the US are born intersex or with DSD.\n\nIntersex women have defended Khelif, saying that she should be allowed to compete in her category because she is a woman. Pictured left is Alyssa Ball, an activist for the community who is intersex, and right is Hannah Twigg, an intersex woman from the UK who aims to raise awareness about the condition\n\nKhelif was forced to speak out and call upon boxing fans to refrain from bullying the athletes earlier this week\n\nKhelif, who was registered female at birth, has been at the heart of a gender row after the IBA disqualified her from the World Championships last year. She is pictured at the Paris Olympics\n\nAlyssa Ball, who is also intersex and raises awareness of the condition, told DailyMail.com: 'I feel pretty emotionally exhausted speaking about the subject matter at hand.\n\n'As an intersex person, of course I think she should be allowed to compete.\n\n'Whatever \"advantages\" she may have are comparable to say someone else born with a physical build that is most advantageous for whatever sport.'\n\nDr Tommy Lundberg, a lecturer in physiology at Sweden's Karolinska Instituet, disagreed, however, saying she likely had a biological advantage because she has likely gone through male puberty.\n\nHe said: 'If Khelif does have 5-ARD, then that's considered male development during puberty and therefore and advantage.\n\n'Being male is not a talent and should not be rewarded more than being female.\n\n'The inclusion of athletes with male performance advantages in women's sport if a violation of the very important principles of fair and safe competition for female athletes.'\n\nIn tonight's fight, Khelif beat her competitor Janjaem Suwannapheng after overpowering the plucky opponent and landing bigger shots -- before cruising to victory with a unanimous verdict.\n\nRules on testosterone limits had been previously brought into sharp focus by Caster Semenya, who was barred from women's track events after it emerged she had elevated testosterone levels\n\nShe was cheered on by a noisy Algerian crowd, who were shouting 'Imane' before their boxer had even entered the arena.\n\nAfter winning, she skipped victorious circles around the arena before leaving to more cheers -- ahead of her fight for the gold on Friday.\n\nFiona McAnena, who works with scientists who research sex differences and is a director at UK-based women's sports charity Sex Matters, also said she likely had an advantage.\n\nShe said: 'It is not the fault of these young people that they have a congenital [developmental] condition and are registered as female when their chromosomes are male. This may be a shocking, surprising and traumatic thing even, to find out about.\n\n'But all of that aside, women's sport is set up for people who have a woman's advantage and not a male advantage.\n\n'If competitors have a male advantage, and have been through male puberty, then they don't belong in women's sport.'\n\nKhelif's condition is not public, leaving experts only able to speculate on whether or not she may have a condition and, if so, which one.\n\nBut a recent statement tweak from the International Olympic Committee (IOC) suggests that she may be intersex.\n\nOn August 3, they updated a statement where they said 'this is not a Differences of Sexual Development' case' to 'this is not a transgender case'.\n\nFor her part, Khelif has said that she is a woman and vowed to continue competing.\n\nIn a statement, she said: 'I address my message to all the people of the world to adhere to the Olympic principles, according to the Olympic Charter, and to avoid bullying all athletes, because this has a great impact.\n\n'It is capable of destroying people, killing people's thinking and minds, and dividing people.'\n\nShe previously dismissed the decision to ban her from the IBA's competition as a 'conspiracy' to stop an Algerian winning.\n\nKhelif's native Algeria has strong anti-LGBT laws in place, and its society does not tolerate transgender individuals.\n\nThe IOC interprets someone's gender at face value based on what is written in their passports.\n\nThey are also running the women's boxing competition amid a separate dispute with the IBA, which was barred from involvement.\n\nIn other categories, however, such as swimming -- the association reserves the right to test athletes when there are concerns they may have a biological advantage.\n\nExperts suggest the same should be done in boxing, saying it can be determined whether someone has gone through male puberty using a blood test -- which can pick up higher levels of testosterone.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imane_Khelif", "type": "wiki", These allegations were false, as Snopes has covered.\n\nAs we explained in that previous article, Khelif was disqualified from the 2023 International Boxing Association World Championships in New Delhi after a genetic test -- the details of which the IBA has described as \"confidential\" -- allegedly found results consistent with the male sex.\n\nRegardless of the nature of the 2023 IBA test, the International Olympic Committee determined Khelif eligible to compete as a woman in the 2024 Olympics, as an IOC representative told The Associated Press on Aug. 2, 2024. There is no evidence that Khelif has ever identified as male or transgender.\n\nThe document in question appears in video footage credited to Reuters and shared on YouTube by Philippines-based ABS-CBN News, also on Aug. 3, 2024. The document, a booklet with both printed and handwritten text in Arabic, can be seen starting around the 2:25 timestamp in the video below:\n\nIn the Reuters interview, Amar Khelif said, \"This is our family official document, May 2, 1999, Imane Khelif, female. It is written here you can read it, this document doesn't lie.\"\n\nSnopes has not independently authenticated the existence or the contents of the document shown in the video. {"uri": "8262624895", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-07", "time": "00:16:39", "dateTime": "2024-08-07T00:16:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-07T00:15:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://www.marca.com/en/boxing/2024/08/07/66b2b516268e3e60708b457b.html", "title": "Imane Khelif dominates, advances to Gold Medal round", "body": "Algerian boxer Imane Khelifis on the brink of Olympic gold in the women's 66 kg welterweight division after a decisive victory against Thailand's Janjaem Suwannapheng. Khelif's unanimous 5-0 win at the Paris Games showcased her dominance and precision, leaving no doubt about her control over the bout.\n\nKhelif's performance was a masterclass in boxing, dictating the pace from the first round to the last. Her superior technique and frequent, well-placed punches kept Suwannapheng on the defensive, though a knockout never seemed imminent. The crowd at Roland Garros, vibrant with Algerian flags and chants, clearly favored Khelif, creating an electrifying atmosphere.\n\nHowever, Khelif's journey to the gold medal round hasn't been without controversy. Her eligibility has been a hot topic since Italian boxer Angela Carini forfeited their match after just 46 seconds, citing the unprecedented strength of Khelif's punches. This incident brought Khelif's gender into the spotlight, as she had failed a gender test administered by the International Boxing Association (IBA) in 2023, despite being listed as female on her passport.\n\nThe circumstances surrounding Khelif's gender test have been murky. The IBA, criticized for its ties to Russia and its split from the International Olympic Committee (IOC), has faced questions about the criteria and administration of these tests. The timing of Khelif's test, following her victory over a Russian opponent, has only fueled further speculation.\n\nThe stage is now set for Friday afternoon's final, where Khelif will fight for gold. Her journey, marked by both triumph and controversy, has captivated audiences worldwide, making her one of the most talked-about athletes at the Paris Games.", "source": {"uri": "marca.com", {"uri": "8258529234", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-08-04", "time": "11:00:12", "dateTime": "2024-08-04T11:00:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-08-04T10:59:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://www.bangkokpost.com/sports/2841263/thailand-secures-olympic-medals-in-badminton-and-boxing", "title": "Thailand secures Olympic medals in badminton, boxing", "body": "FRANCE: The long wait for Thai sports fans is finally over as talented shuttler Kunlavut Vitidsarn and boxer Janjaem Suwannapheng have assured the kingdom of its first medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics.\n\nWhen Janjaem punched her ticket to the women's 66kg semi-finals, which guarantee at least a bronze medal, with an upset victory over top-ranked Busenaz Surmeneli of Turkey on Saturday night, a sense of joy gripped the nation.\n\nKunlavut followed it up with a sterling show Sunday afternoon to give Thailand its first-ever Olympic badminton medal as he overwhelmed Malaysia's Lee Zii Jia 21-14, 21-15 in the men's single semi-finals at Porte de La Chapelle Arena in Paris.\n\nThe victory has earned Kunlavut, the reigning world champion, a shot at the gold medal. He will face either defending champion Viktor Axelsen of Denmark or Lakshya Sen of India in the title showdown on Monday.\n\nJanjaem, a 23-year-old from Nong Khai, did well to defeat Surmeneli, who won the gold medal in the 69kg category at Tokyo 2020, 4-1 at North Paris Arena.\n\nJanjaem has become only the second Thai female boxer to win an Olympic medal after Sudaporn Seesondee, who claimed a bronze medal in the women's 60kg class in Tokyo three years ago.\n\nAwaiting the Thai fighter in the last four is Imane Khelif, the Algerian boxer embroiled in a gender controversy.\n\nKhelif, 25, defeated Hungary's Anna Luca Hamori with a unanimous points decision to reach the semi-finals and to ensure at least a bronze medal -- Algeria's first in the sport since 2000.\n\nJanjaem lost to Khelif at the world championships in New Delhi last year but later progressed to the final after the Algerian was disqualified. She lost to China's Liu Yang in the final.\n\n\"I know the Algerian boxer is very strong and I will try to watch her video to learn her tactics and correct mine accordingly,\" Janjaem said of Khelif.\n\nReflecting on her stunning victory over Surmeneli, a beaming Janjaem said, \"I'm so happy that I won today.\n\n\"I felt a bit of pressure because I knew that I was the only Thai boxer left in the tournament and I was up against a top-ranked boxer in the division.\n\n\"But I think Thai people will now know more about me. I think my parents back home must be so happy.\"\n\n\"I hope Thai people will continue to support me in my next fight,\" added Janjaem, who was a silver medallist at the Hangzhou Asian Games last year.\n\nFellow Thai boxer Chuthamat Raksat lost to China's Wu Yu 5-0 in the 50kg quarter-finals. Wu also beat Chuthamat in the final at the Hangzhou Asian Games last year.\n\nMeanwhile, badminton has now become the fourth sport to produce an Olympic Games medal for Thailand after boxing, weightlifting and taekwondo.\n\nKunlavut has been in stellar form in Paris.\n\nHe stunned world No.1 Shi Yuqi of China in the quarter-finals on Friday and the 23-year-old continued his fantastic run to the final with an impressive victory over Lee in 51 minutes.\n\nDespite competing in every Olympic Games since 1992, the closest Thai badminton players got to a podium finish was at Athens 2004, when Boonsak Ponsana reached the men's singles semi-final before losing to the eventual champion Taufik Hidayat of Indonesia.\n\nBoonsak was also beaten in the bronze medal match by Sony Dawi Kuncoro "sim": 0.4392156898975372, "url": "https://www.bangkokpost.com/sports/2841947/janjaem-set-for-epic-semi-final-battle", "title": "Janjaem set for epic semi-final battle", "body": "Paris: Janjaem Suwannapheng will take on Imane Khelif of Algeria in the women's 66kg semi-finals tonight, hoping to enter the Thai history books by becoming the country's first female boxer to earn a shot at an Olympic gold medal.\n\nJanjaem will be determined to surpass Sudaporn Seesondee's feat of claiming the bronze medal at the Covid-delayed Tokyo 2020 three years ago when she bowed out in the last four round of the women's 60kg category.\n\nSudaporn lost 3-2 to top seed and eventual champion Kellie Harrington of Ireland, but only after becoming Thailand's first female boxer to win a Games medal.\n\nJanjaem, a two-time world championship medallist and a runner-up at the Hangzhou Asian Games last year, will face a formidable opponent in Khelif, who outclassed Hungary's Anna Luca Hamori to record a unanimous points decision and reach the semi-finals.\n\nJanjaem, however, is also in top form after her stunning victory over top-ranked Busenaz Surmeneli of Turkey in the quarter-finals.\n\nThe 23-year-old put on a show of power and precision as she defeated the Tokyo Games champion 4-1 to claim a coveted semi-final spot, which guaranteed her a bronze medal.\n\nJanjaem knows what to expect from Khelif, who beat the Thai at the world championships last year before being disqualified.\n\n\"I know the Algerian boxer is very strong and I will try to watch her video to learn her tactics and correct mine,\" Janjaem said of Khelif.\n\nJanjaem's victory over Surmeneli in the quarter-finals has not only ensured Thailand's first medal of the Paris Games, but also deflected some of the criticism being hurled at the country's boxing contingent for its disappointing campaign.\n\nThailand have sent eight boxers -- three men and five women -- to Paris and Janjaem is the only one left in the tournament.\n\nBunjong Sinsiri went furthest in the men's competition before losing to Erislandy Alvarez Borges of Cuba 5-0 in the quarter-finals of the men's 63.5kg category.\n\nWith the exception of Rio 2016, Thailand's boxing team have won at least a medal in every Olympics since the 1976 Montreal Games.\n\nPuripol vows better show\n\nThai sprinter Puripol Boonson clocked 10.14sec to finish 21st overall in the men's 100m semi-finals on Sunday and failed to qualify for the final.\n\nThere were 27 runners competing in three semi-finals, and Puripol came ninth in third semi-final.\n\nThe gold medal went to American Noah Lyles, who won in the closest Olympic 100m finish in modern history as just five thousandths of a second separated him from Jamaica's Kishane Thompson.\n\nThe 18-year-old Puripol vowed to do better in four years' time.\n\n\"In four years, I will be stronger and will try to get a medal for Thailand,\" said Puripol, who was the youngest runner in the 100m field in Paris.\n\n\"All the athletes are very strong and so powerful, so I will have to work hard on building up my body.\n\nHe added, \"The Olympics is the biggest event I've competed in. When I got into the stadium and saw how big the crowd was... it was something I never experienced before. In the next Olympics, I will not be so nervous like I was this time!\"\n\nCyclist Phetdarin Somrat finished in 78th place in the women's road race event on Sunday, crossing the line 14:19 behind winner Kristen Faulkner of the US (3:59.23).
